We confess that we often find ourselves drawn to the shadows, preferring the fleeting comforts of sin over the enduring light of your presence. Forgive us for loving the darkness and for the deeds that are evil in your sight. Illuminate our hearts, Lord, and help us to see the truth. Grant us the courage to turn from our wicked ways and to walk in the light of your Son, Jesus Christ. Give us a hunger for righteousness and a desire to live a life that pleases you. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, so that we may be transformed from darkness to light. Help us to share your light with others, so that they too may find salvation and everlasting life, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-26.versiculo: Titus 2:11-14 KJV: "For the grace of God that bringeth salvation hath appeared to all men, Teaching us that, denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world; Looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ; Who gave himself for us, that he might redeem us from all iniquity, and purify unto himself a peculiar people, zealous of good works."
2025-11-26.reflexion: The Apostle Paul's words in Titus 2:11-14 are a powerful summary of the Christian life. It begins with the proclamation that God's grace, the unearned favor that brings salvation, has appeared to all. This grace isn't just a theoretical concept; it's a transformative power. It teaches us to deny ungodliness and worldly lusts, a constant battle against the desires that pull us away from God. This denial is not an end in itself, but a means to an end: to live soberly, righteously, and godly in this present world. The 'present world' is not a place to be escaped, but a field of opportunity to live out our faith. We are to be distinct, not isolated, demonstrating the reality of God's grace through our lives.  The passage then points us toward the blessed hope of Christ’s return. This hope fuels our endurance and motivates our obedience. We eagerly await the glorious appearing of Jesus Christ, our Savior, who gave Himself to redeem us from all iniquity. This redemption is both a past act, securing our forgiveness, and a present work, purifying us to be a people zealous for good works. Our good works are not a means to earn salvation, but the natural outflow of a heart transformed by God’s grace.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.

I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.
But as he which hath called you is holy, so be ye holy in all manner of conversation; Because it is written, Be ye holy; for I am holy.

2025-11-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the immeasurable grace that has been extended to us, bringing salvation to all who believe. Help us to understand the transformative power of Your grace, enabling us to deny ungodliness and worldly desires. Grant us the strength to live soberly, righteously, and godly in this present world, reflecting Your love and light in all that we do. Fill our hearts with the blessed hope of Christ's return, that we may eagerly anticipate His glorious appearing. Purify us from all iniquity and make us zealous for good works, demonstrating the fruit of Your grace in our lives. Guide us to live each day in a manner worthy of Your calling. Give us the wisdom to discern Your will and the courage to follow it faithfully, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-27.versiculo: 2 Timothy 3:17 KJV: "That the man of God may be perfect, thoroughly furnished unto all good works."
2025-11-27.reflexion: Today’s verse from 2 Timothy 3:17 speaks to the ultimate goal of spiritual development: to become fully equipped for every good work. This verse follows a passage detailing the importance of Scripture for teaching, reproof, correction, and instruction in righteousness. It's not merely about accumulating knowledge; it's about transformation. The 'man of God' – or woman of God – is not defined by inherent perfection but by the ongoing process of being made complete, or 'perfected,' through the diligent use of God's Word. 'Thoroughly furnished' implies a complete equipping, not just a superficial understanding. It suggests a practical readiness for every good work, every opportunity to serve God and others. This involves a life lived in obedience to Christ, guided by the principles found in the Bible. It requires a willingness to learn, to be corrected, and to grow in righteousness. It's a call to active discipleship, where faith is demonstrated through works, motivated by love and empowered by the Holy Spirit. This verse serves as a powerful reminder that our spiritual journey is not a passive one; it demands intentionality and a commitment to being shaped by the Word of God. It is a process that leads to greater usefulness in God’s Kingdom.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word have I hid in mine heart, that I might not sin against thee.
But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.
For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them.

2025-11-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of Your Word, which equips us for every good work. Help us to diligently study and meditate on Your Scriptures, allowing them to shape our thoughts, words, and actions. Grant us the wisdom to understand Your truth and the strength to live it out in our daily lives. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit so that we may be thoroughly equipped for every opportunity to serve You and to love others. Help us to be doers of Your Word, not hearers only, and to walk in the good works You have prepared for us. Guide us to be transformed by the renewing of our minds, so that we may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God. We pray all these things in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-28.versiculo: Philippians 4:6-7 KJV: "Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God. And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus."
2025-11-28.reflexion: Today's passage from Philippians 4:6-7 offers a powerful antidote to the anxieties of life. We are instructed to 'be careful for nothing,' a direct command to cast off worry and fretfulness. The solution? A deliberate turning towards prayer and supplication, accompanied by thanksgiving. This is not merely a passive request, but an active engagement with God, presenting our needs and concerns with gratitude for His provision. The result of this practice is the unparalleled 'peace of God, which passeth all understanding.' This peace is not merely the absence of turmoil, but a profound tranquility that guards our hearts and minds through Christ Jesus. It's a peace that transcends human comprehension, a supernatural protection against the storms of life. This passage encourages us to actively cultivate a life of prayer, replacing anxiety with gratitude and trusting in God's unwavering presence. It's a call to embrace the peace that surpasses all understanding, a promise of security and serenity in the midst of life's challenges.

para_meditar.texto: Cast thy burden upon the LORD, and he shall sustain thee: he shall never suffer the righteous to be moved.

Therefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on. Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment? Behold the fowls of the air: for they sow not, neither do they reap, nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father feedeth them. Are ye not much better than they? Which of you by taking thought can add one cubit unto his stature?
Casting all your care upon him; for he careth for you.

2025-11-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today, burdened by the cares and anxieties of this life. I confess that I often allow worry to consume my thoughts, clouding my peace and hindering my trust in You. Help me to remember the command in Philippians to 'be careful for nothing,' and to instead turn to You in prayer and supplication. I offer You my requests with thanksgiving, knowing that You are a loving and caring God. Grant me the peace that surpasses all understanding, a peace that guards my heart and mind in Christ Jesus. Help me to cast all my cares upon You, knowing that You care for me. Fill me with Your peace, and guide me in every step of my journey. Thank you for Your faithfulness and Your unwavering love, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-29.versiculo: James 1:12 KJV: "Blessed is the man that endureth temptation: for when he is tried, he shall receive the crown of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love him."
2025-11-29.reflexion: Today's verse, James 1:12, offers profound encouragement amidst the trials of life. It speaks of a blessed state, a promise of reward for those who persevere through temptation. The word 'blessed' isn't just a sentiment; it denotes a deep, intrinsic happiness, a spiritual flourishing that comes from enduring difficult times. The 'temptation' mentioned encompasses a wide range of challenges – trials, difficulties, and tests of faith. It's not merely about resisting sin, but about the overall process of being refined. The verse highlights that through these trials, we are 'tried,' or tested. This testing is a crucible, a process by which our faith is purified and strengthened. The promised 'crown of life' is not just a reward; it's a symbol of eternal life and the ultimate inheritance for those who love God. It is a promise made to those who demonstrate their love through faithful obedience and perseverance. This verse encourages us to embrace trials, knowing that they are opportunities for growth, strengthening our faith, and ultimately leading us to the promised reward. It reminds us that suffering has a purpose, and that God's promises are for those who remain steadfast in their love for Him.

para_meditar.texto: And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience; And patience, experience; and experience, hope: And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us.

Wherein ye greatly rejoice, though now for a season, if need be, ye are in heaviness through manifold temptations: That the trial of your faith, being much more precious than of gold that perisheth, though it be tried with fire, might be found unto praise and honour and glory at the appearing of Jesus Christ:
Now no chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous: nevertheless afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness unto them which are exercised thereby.

2025-11-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the promise found in James 1:12. Thank you for the trials and temptations that refine us and strengthen our faith. Help us to endure through the difficult times, knowing that you are with us, and that the crown of life awaits those who love you. Give us the strength to resist temptation and to persevere in our walk with you. Grant us the wisdom to understand the purpose behind every trial, and the grace to find joy in the midst of suffering. Fill our hearts with your love, that we may love you with all our heart, soul, and mind. Guide us to walk in obedience and to remain steadfast in our faith, so that we may receive the eternal reward you have promised. We pray for the strength to be a light in this world, and to share the hope we have in you. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-30.versiculo: Matthew 21:21-22 KJV: "Jesus answered and said unto them, Verily I say unto you, If ye have faith, and doubt not, ye shall not only do this which is done to the fig tree, but also if ye shall say unto this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea; it shall be done. And all things, whatsoever ye shall ask in prayer, believing, ye shall receive."
2025-11-30.reflexion: Today's passage from Matthew 21:21-22 is a powerful testament to the transformative power of faith. Jesus, speaking to his disciples, emphasizes that with faith, nothing is impossible. He uses the example of the fig tree, withered by his word, as a demonstration of the power that resides in believing. He then extends this promise, stating that even mountains can be moved if we believe and do not doubt. This is not merely about physical acts; it is about the spiritual realm. It speaks to the unwavering trust we must have in God's power and promises. The key ingredient is faith, a deep-seated conviction that God is able to do what He has promised. This faith must be coupled with prayer, the act of communicating with God, and believing that we will receive what we ask for. This passage challenges us to examine the depth of our faith. Are we truly believing, or are we allowing doubt to creep in? Do we approach prayer with expectation, or with a hesitant heart? This is a call to step out in faith, trusting in God's ability to move in our lives and in the world around us.

para_meditar.texto: Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
Therefore I say unto you, What things soever ye desire, when ye pray, believe that ye receive them, and ye shall have them.
But let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea driven with the wind and tossed.

2025-11-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts seeking to deepen our faith. We confess that we often struggle with doubt and find ourselves hesitant to believe in the power of your promises. Forgive us for the times we have lacked faith and allowed fear to hold us back. Help us, Lord, to cultivate an unwavering belief in your ability to do exceedingly and abundantly above all that we ask or think. Grant us the courage to pray with boldness, trusting that you hear us and that you are working on our behalf. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may be empowered to move mountains of doubt and fear in our lives and in the lives of others. Give us the faith to believe that all things are possible through you. We thank you for your love, your grace, and your faithfulness. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-01.versiculo: Galatians 5:16 KJV: "This I say then, Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh."
2025-12-01.reflexion: Today's verse from Galatians 5:16 is a powerful call to action: "Walk in the Spirit." This isn't merely a suggestion; it's an imperative, a command to actively engage with the Holy Spirit. The promise that follows – "and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh" – offers liberation from the internal battle against sinful desires. The "flesh" here represents our fallen nature, our inherent inclination towards self-centeredness and disobedience. It's the part of us that craves instant gratification, that succumbs to temptation, and that separates us from God. But the Spirit offers a different path. When we choose to walk in the Spirit, we actively cultivate a relationship with God, seeking His guidance and power. This involves prayer, reading Scripture, fellowship with other believers, and obedience to His commandments. It’s a daily decision, a conscious choice to align our thoughts, desires, and actions with the will of God. The more we walk in the Spirit, the less power the flesh has over us. It's a process of transformation, a journey of sanctification, where we become more like Christ each day, finding true freedom and joy in obedience to Him.

para_meditar.texto: For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit.
For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.
And be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess; but be filled with the Spirit.

2025-12-01.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today seeking Your guidance and strength. I acknowledge my struggles with the desires of the flesh and my need for Your Holy Spirit. I pray for the grace to walk in the Spirit, to be led by Your wisdom and filled with Your love. Help me to recognize the temptations that seek to pull me away from You and give me the power to resist them. Renew my mind, transform my heart, and empower me to live a life that is pleasing in Your sight. Fill me with the fruits of the Spirit – love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control. Help me to daily choose to walk in Your ways, to seek Your presence, and to live a life that glorifies You. Thank you for Your promise of freedom and victory over sin. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-02.versiculo: 1 Timothy 6:17-19 KJV: "Charge them that are rich in this world, that they be not highminded, nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God, who giveth us richly all things to enjoy; That they do good, that they be rich in good works, ready to distribute, willing to communicate; Laying up in store for themselves a good foundation against the time to come, that they may lay hold on eternal life."
2025-12-02.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Timothy 6:17-19 offers a powerful reminder about the dangers of wealth and the true meaning of riches in God's eyes. Paul addresses the rich, not with condemnation, but with instruction. He warns against pride and placing trust in the fleeting nature of material wealth. Instead, he directs them to trust in the living God, the ultimate provider of all things. The key is not the *possession* of riches, but the *disposition* of the heart. Paul calls the wealthy to be generous, to do good works, and to be ready to share. This isn't just about charity; it's about investing in eternal rewards. By using their resources to bless others, they are building a foundation for the future, securing their grasp on eternal life. This passage challenges us to examine our own hearts. Are we trusting in God, or in the things we can hold? Are we generous with our time, talents, and treasures? Are we investing in eternity or just the present? It is not about the absence of wealth, but the presence of a generous heart and a faith rooted in God's eternal promises.

para_meditar.texto: Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal: But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal.
The liberal soul shall be made fat: and he that watereth shall be watered also himself.
So is he that layeth up treasure for himself, and is not rich toward God.

2025-12-02.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You acknowledging that all good things come from You. Help us to be mindful of the blessings You have bestowed upon us, both material and spiritual. Deliver us from the temptation to be prideful or to trust in the uncertainty of riches. Grant us generous hearts, that we may be willing to share and to do good works for Your glory. Guide us to invest in eternal treasures, building a foundation of faith and love. Help us to see the needs of others and to be a blessing in their lives. Give us the wisdom to use our resources wisely, honoring You in all we do. May we always remember that true riches lie in a relationship with You and in serving others. We ask for Your guidance and strength in this endeavor, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-03.versiculo: Mark 8:34 KJV: "And when he had called the people unto him with his disciples also, he said unto them, Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me."
2025-12-03.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 8:34, presents a stark yet essential truth about following Christ: self-denial, taking up one's cross, and following Him. This is not a suggestion, but a prerequisite. Jesus, surrounded by the crowd and His disciples, sets the terms of discipleship. He calls for a complete surrender of self. 'Deny himself' speaks to a deliberate rejection of our own desires, ambitions, and comfort in favor of God's will. It's a turning away from the self-centeredness that plagues humanity. 'Take up his cross' signifies a willingness to endure suffering, hardship, and even death for the sake of the Gospel. The cross, a symbol of shame and execution, represents the ultimate sacrifice. To take it up means to be ready to suffer for Christ. Finally, 'follow me' is the call to action. It is not enough to simply believe; we must actively follow Jesus, emulating His life, obeying His teachings, and seeking His guidance in all things. This is not an easy path, but it is the path to true life and fulfillment. It demands a radical transformation of our priorities and a commitment to living a life centered on Christ, not ourselves. The rewards, however, are eternal and immeasurable.

para_meditar.texto: Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me.
I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.

2025-12-03.oracion: Dear Lord, I come before You today acknowledging my own weaknesses and self-centeredness. I confess that I often cling to my own desires and comfort, rather than seeking Your will. Help me to deny myself and to embrace the cross You have set before me. Grant me the strength to endure hardship and suffering for Your sake. Open my eyes to see Your presence in all circumstances. Lead me, guide me, and give me the courage to follow You wholeheartedly. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit so that I may live a life that truly reflects Your love and grace. Help me to remember that the path of discipleship is not easy, but it is the path to eternal life. Thank you for your unending grace and mercy. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-04.versiculo: Ephesians 6:10-13 KJV: "Finally, my brethren, be strong in the Lord, and in the power of his might. Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil. For we wrestle not against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this world, against spiritual wickedness in high places. Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand."
2025-12-04.reflexion: Today's passage from Ephesians calls us to a profound understanding of spiritual warfare. Paul implores us to be strong in the Lord and in the power of His might. This is not a call to physical strength, but a summons to draw on the limitless power available to us through our relationship with Christ. The 'whole armour of God' is not merely a metaphorical concept; it is a practical guide to navigating the spiritual battles that we inevitably face. We are reminded that our struggle is not against people, but against the forces of evil that seek to undermine our faith and purpose. These are not tangible enemies, but rather principalities, powers, and spiritual wickedness. The 'evil day' is not a specific future event, but the constant reality of living in a fallen world, where temptation and opposition abound. To withstand this, we must fully equip ourselves with the armor of God: truth, righteousness, peace, faith, salvation, and the word of God. This is not a passive defense, but an active engagement in spiritual warfare, constantly seeking to live according to God's will and to be a light in a dark world.

para_meditar.texto: Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.
Be sober, be vigilant; because your adversary the devil, as a roaring lion, walketh about, seeking whom he may devour:
(For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the pulling down of strong holds;)

2025-12-04.oracion: Dear Lord, I come before you today acknowledging my need for your strength and guidance. Help me to be strong in you and in the power of your might, so that I may withstand the wiles of the devil. Grant me the wisdom to recognize the spiritual battles I face and the courage to put on the whole armor of God. Clothe me with truth, righteousness, and peace. Shield my faith and salvation, and make your word a lamp unto my feet and a light unto my path. Help me to stand firm in the evil day, knowing that I am more than a conqueror through Christ who loves me. Give me the discernment to resist temptation and the grace to live a life that honors you. Guide my steps and keep me safe from the attacks of the enemy. I ask for your protection and guidance, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-05.versiculo: Mark 9:23 KJV: "Jesus said unto him, If thou canst believe, all things are possible to him that believeth."
2025-12-05.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 9:23, is a powerful declaration of the transformative power of faith. Jesus, responding to a father's plea for his demon-possessed son, doesn't focus on the impossibility of the situation. Instead, He directs the focus inward, challenging the father's belief. The phrase, "If thou canst believe," is not a question of physical ability, but a test of the heart. It's a call to examine the depth of our trust in God's power. The second part of the verse, "all things are possible to him that believeth," is a promise of limitless potential. It doesn't guarantee that every desire will be granted, but it does assure that through faith, we can overcome any obstacle and achieve what may seem impossible. This verse reminds us that our limitations are often self-imposed, stemming from a lack of faith. It encourages us to release our doubts and embrace the unwavering belief that with God, all things are possible. To truly believe is to act as if God's power is already at work, seeking His will above our own, and trusting in His perfect timing and plan.

para_meditar.texto: Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.

And Jesus said unto them, Because of your unbelief: for verily I say unto you, If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say unto this mountain, Remove hence to yonder place; and it shall remove; and nothing shall be impossible unto you.
So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.

2025-12-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today with a heart that desires to believe. I confess that doubt sometimes creeps in, clouding my vision and hindering my faith. Help me to trust in your power, even when faced with seemingly impossible situations. Remove the barriers of unbelief that stand between me and your grace. Grant me the strength to believe in your promises, to act on my faith, and to witness the miracles you have prepared for me. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may be guided by your wisdom and strengthened by your unwavering love. Help me to remember that with You, all things are possible, and to live each day with the assurance of Your presence. I pray for the courage to step out in faith, knowing that You are with me always, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-06.versiculo: 1 John 5:13 KJV: "These things have I written unto you that believe on the name of the Son of God; that ye may know that ye have eternal life, and that ye may believe on the name of the Son of God."
2025-12-06.reflexion: The Apostle John, in his first epistle, penned these powerful words to provide assurance and clarity to believers. 1 John 5:13 isn't just a statement; it's a declaration of purpose. John wrote to those who believe, not to those who are merely curious, but to those whose hearts have been transformed by faith in Jesus Christ. His intention was twofold: to affirm their possession of eternal life and to strengthen their belief in the very name of the Son of God. This verse underscores the profound connection between faith, knowledge, and the assurance of salvation. It's not about intellectual assent alone; it's about a living, breathing faith that is anchored in the person and work of Jesus. John wants us to *know*. He doesn't want us to be perpetually questioning or doubting. He desires that we experience the peace and certainty that comes from knowing we are secure in Christ. This knowledge is not based on our own merits or good works, but on the finished work of Jesus on the cross. It's a gift, freely given to those who believe. Let us therefore embrace this truth, allowing it to permeate our hearts and minds, strengthening our faith and emboldening us to live a life worthy of the calling we have received.

para_meditar.texto: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
He that believeth on the Son hath everlasting life: and he that believeth not the Son shall not see life; but the wrath of God abideth on him.
Let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience, and our bodies washed with pure water.

2025-12-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the assurance of eternal life that you have given to us through faith in your Son, Jesus Christ. We are grateful for the Holy Spirit's witness within us, confirming that we are indeed your children. Lord, help us to grow in our knowledge of your Word and to deepen our faith in your name. Remove any doubt or uncertainty that may cloud our minds, and fill us with the peace that surpasses all understanding. Grant us the courage to live boldly for you, sharing the good news of salvation with others. May we always remember the gift of eternal life, and may it motivate us to live a life that glorifies you in every way. Thank you for your love and grace. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-07.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 15:57 KJV: "But thanks be to God, which giveth us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ."
2025-12-07.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 15:57, is a resounding declaration of triumph! Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, exclaims, "But thanks be to God, which giveth us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ." This isn't a passive expression of gratitude; it's a bold proclamation of victory over death, sin, and the grave. The context of this verse is the resurrection of Christ, the cornerstone of our faith. Without the resurrection, our faith is in vain (1 Corinthians 15:14). But because Jesus conquered death, we too have victory! The 'victory' isn't just a future promise; it's a present reality. Through Jesus Christ, we are already victorious! This victory encompasses forgiveness of sins, freedom from the power of sin, and the promise of eternal life. It’s a gift freely given, not earned through our own efforts. It reminds us that our struggles, our doubts, and our fears are not the final word. The final word is Jesus. The final word is victory. Let us therefore live each day with gratitude, recognizing that the victory is ours, secured by the grace of God through our Lord Jesus Christ. Let us walk in the power of this victory, sharing the good news with all those around us.

para_meditar.texto: Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.
I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
These things I have spoken unto you, that in me ye might have peace. In the world ye shall have tribulation: but be of good cheer; I have overcome the world.

2025-12-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts filled with gratitude. Thank you for the ultimate victory won for us through your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank you that we are not condemned, but redeemed and given new life. Help us to grasp the magnitude of this victory, to understand the power we have through Christ. Grant us the strength to live each day reflecting this victory, overcoming sin and temptation. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may be bold witnesses of your love and grace. May we share the good news of salvation with others, so that they too may know the joy of victory. We praise you for your unwavering love and faithfulness, and we commit our lives to your service, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-08.versiculo: Romans 10:13 KJV: "For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved."
2025-12-08.reflexion: Romans 10:13 is a cornerstone of the Christian faith, a simple yet profound declaration of salvation. It's a promise offered to all, regardless of background, status, or past deeds. The verse hinges on two key actions: 'call upon' and 'the name of the Lord.' To 'call upon' signifies more than a casual utterance; it implies a heartfelt plea, a recognition of need, and a dependence on God. It's a cry from the depths of one's being, acknowledging His sovereignty and mercy. 'The name of the Lord' encompasses the entirety of God's character and attributes – His love, grace, power, and holiness. Calling upon His name is a complete surrender to Him, a recognition of His Lordship. The promise attached is equally significant: 'shall be saved.' Salvation, in this context, is not merely an escape from punishment but a transformation, a restoration of relationship with God, and the inheritance of eternal life. This verse is a powerful invitation to anyone struggling with their own brokenness, offering a clear path to redemption. It encourages us to embrace faith and take the necessary step of calling upon the Lord, knowing that He will unfailingly answer the cry of those who seek Him.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
And it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord shall be saved.

Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name: That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

2025-12-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today acknowledging my need for your grace and mercy. Lord, I confess my sins and my dependence on You. I open my heart to You, recognizing Your Lordship and Your unwavering love. I call upon Your name, believing in the power of Jesus' sacrifice and the promise of salvation. Help me to live a life that honors You, reflecting Your love and sharing the good news with others. Grant me strength and guidance as I navigate this life, and draw me closer to You each and every day. I thank you for the gift of eternal life and for the hope that is found in Your name. Help me to trust in Your plans for my life, even when things are difficult and uncertain. Thank you for hearing my prayer and answering me, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-09.versiculo: 1 John 4:19 KJV: "We love him, because he first loved us."
2025-12-09.reflexion: Today's verse, "We love him, because he first loved us," is a powerful declaration of the foundation of Christian love. It underscores the crucial truth that our capacity to love God and, by extension, to love others, is a direct response to His prior and unending love for us. This isn't a love that we earn; it’s a gift, freely given, even before we knew Him. The Apostle John, in writing this, emphasizes the reciprocal nature of our relationship with God. Our love isn't the initiator; His is. His love is the wellspring from which our love flows. Before we can love God, we must first recognize and receive His love. This recognition allows us to understand the depth of His grace and the magnitude of His sacrifice. It enables us to see ourselves through His eyes, as beloved children, worthy of His affection. This understanding transforms our hearts, creating a genuine desire to love Him in return. This verse challenges us to reflect on whether we truly understand the extent of God's love for us. Are we living in the awareness of His constant affection? Are we allowing His love to shape our thoughts, actions, and relationships? May we embrace His love and, in turn, love others with the same grace and compassion that He has shown us.

para_meditar.texto: But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us, Even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved;)
For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.

2025-12-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for Your boundless love, a love that surpasses all understanding. Thank you for loving us first, even when we were lost and unworthy. Help us to fully grasp the depth of Your affection and to live each day in the awareness of Your grace. Open our hearts to receive Your love and allow it to overflow into our relationships with others. Grant us the ability to love You with all our heart, soul, and mind, and to love our neighbors as ourselves. Transform our lives, Lord, that we may reflect Your love in everything we do. Guide us to share Your love with a world that desperately needs it. May we always remember that we are loved, and may we always seek to love You and others in return. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-10.versiculo: Galatians 6:14 KJV: "But God forbid that I should glory, save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world."
2025-12-10.reflexion: Today's verse, Galatians 6:14, is a powerful declaration of the Apostle Paul’s singular focus: the cross of Jesus Christ. He refuses to boast in anything else. This verse speaks to a radical shift in perspective, a complete reorientation of values. Paul understands that true glory, true worth, and true redemption come solely through the sacrifice of Jesus. The world, with its allure and its false promises, is crucified to him. He is no longer bound by its standards, its desires, or its approval. Similarly, Paul is crucified to the world. He no longer seeks its validation or lives by its rules. This is a profound statement of separation and devotion. It's a declaration of freedom from the chains of worldly ambition, materialism, and the constant striving for personal gain. It’s a call to embrace a life defined by the cross, a life of humility, self-sacrifice, and unwavering faith. We are reminded to examine our own hearts. What do we truly glory in? What are we truly devoted to? Are we willing to be crucified to the world, that we might live fully for Christ? This verse encourages us to prioritize our relationship with God, putting the cross at the center of our lives, above all else.

para_meditar.texto: Knowing this, that our old man is crucified with him, that the body of sin might be destroyed, that henceforth we should not serve sin.
For the preaching of the cross is to them that perish foolishness; but unto us which are saved it is the power of God.

Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ.

2025-12-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the cross of Jesus Christ, the ultimate expression of your love and grace. Help me to understand the depth of its meaning and the power it holds over sin and death. Grant me the strength to crucify my own desires and ambitions that conflict with Your will. Help me to see the world as you see it, and to resist its temptations. Give me the courage to live a life wholly devoted to you, where my glory is only in the cross of Christ. Fill my heart with Your Holy Spirit, so that I may be transformed into the likeness of Jesus. Renew my mind, so that I may think and act in accordance with Your word. Guide me to live each day with a heart of gratitude and a spirit of humility. Help me to share your gospel with others, so that they, too, may find salvation in Jesus Christ. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-11.versiculo: Acts 20:24 KJV: "But none of these things move me, neither count I my life dear unto myself, so that I might finish my course with joy, and the ministry, which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God."
2025-12-11.reflexion: The Apostle Paul's words in Acts 20:24 resonate with a profound sense of purpose and unwavering dedication. He declares that the tribulations he faces hold no sway over him, nor does he value his own life above the completion of his God-given ministry. This verse encapsulates the essence of sacrificial service and a life lived for a higher calling. Paul's focus is not on personal comfort or safety, but on finishing his race with joy. This joy is not derived from the absence of hardship, but from the fulfillment of God's will. He emphasizes that his ministry is a specific calling, received from the Lord Jesus. This ministry is to testify to the gospel of the grace of God. This grace is the undeserved favor and love extended to humanity through Jesus Christ. Paul's life is a testament to the transformative power of the gospel, inspiring us to embrace our own callings with boldness and unwavering faith. Paul's example challenges us to examine our priorities. Are we willing to sacrifice personal comforts and fears for the sake of the Gospel? Do we embrace our own ministry, however big or small, with joy and dedication, knowing that it is from the Lord Jesus? Let us strive to live a life that reflects the grace of God, even in the face of adversity.

para_meditar.texto: I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.
I have fought a good fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith:
I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.

2025-12-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the example of Paul, who prioritized Your will above all else. Help us to embrace the challenges and difficulties in our lives with the same spirit of joy and dedication. Grant us the strength to focus on the ministry You have given each of us, and to testify to the grace of God in all that we do. Give us courage to not be moved by the things of this world, but to finish our race with joy, knowing that our reward is with You. Guide us to serve You wholeheartedly, and to make our lives a living testimony to Your love and mercy. Open our hearts to the needs of others and help us to share the Gospel in every opportunity. We commit ourselves to You, seeking Your guidance and strength. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-12.versiculo: Romans 14:12 KJV: "So then every one of us shall give account of himself to God."
2025-12-12.reflexion: Romans 14:12 offers a sobering yet vital truth: we will each stand before God and give an account. This isn't a call to fear, but a call to responsibility. It reminds us that our actions, thoughts, and words have eternal implications. The choices we make, big or small, shape the narrative of our lives before God. This verse emphasizes the personal nature of our faith. We cannot hide behind others or rely solely on their righteousness. Each of us is individually accountable. This understanding should motivate us to live lives of integrity, seeking to please God in all that we do. It encourages us to examine our hearts, to confess our shortcomings, and to strive for a deeper relationship with Him. The knowledge of judgment should not cripple us, but rather empower us to live with purpose and diligence, knowing that our ultimate reward is found in His grace and mercy. The weight of this responsibility is balanced by the promise of forgiveness and the gift of salvation through Jesus Christ. It calls us to live with a constant awareness of God's presence, seeking His guidance and striving to reflect His love in every aspect of our lives.

para_meditar.texto: Neither is there any creature that is not manifest in his sight: but all things are naked and opened unto the eyes of him with whom we have to do.
For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ; that every one may receive the things done in his body, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad.

When the Son of man shall come in his glory, and all the holy angels with him, then shall he sit upon the throne of his glory: And before him shall be gathered all nations: and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth his sheep from the goats: And he shall set the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on the left.

2025-12-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you with humble hearts, acknowledging that we will each stand before your judgment seat. Help us to live each day with the awareness of your presence and the weight of our accountability. Grant us the wisdom to make choices that honor you, and the strength to resist temptations. Forgive us for our shortcomings and failures, and cleanse us from all unrighteousness. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may be transformed into the image of your Son, Jesus Christ. Guide our steps, and let our lives be a testament to your grace and mercy. Help us to love others as you have loved us, and to share the good news of salvation with all. We pray for the courage to live lives of integrity and faith, knowing that we will give an account of ourselves to you. We commit our lives to your will, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-13.versiculo: Luke 17:20-21 KJV: "And when he was demanded of the Pharisees, when the kingdom of God should come, he answered them and said, The kingdom of God cometh not with observation: Neither shall they say, Lo here! or, lo there! for, behold, the kingdom of God is within you."
2025-12-13.reflexion: Today's passage from Luke 17:20-21 offers a profound perspective on the Kingdom of God. The Pharisees, preoccupied with outward signs and rituals, inquired about the kingdom's arrival. Jesus's response is revolutionary: the kingdom isn't a visible spectacle, nor a geographical location to be found. Instead, He declares, "the kingdom of God is within you." This statement challenges us to look inward, to examine the state of our hearts and minds. The Kingdom of God is not something to be observed externally, but a reality to be experienced internally. It speaks of a spiritual realm of righteousness, peace, and joy, accessible to those who believe. This passage encourages us to seek God's presence not through external observances alone, but by cultivating an inner life transformed by His love and grace. We must actively nurture the seeds of faith, allowing the Holy Spirit to cultivate the Kingdom within us. This is a call to introspection and spiritual growth, reminding us that the most significant transformation occurs within the heart, where God's Kingdom truly resides. We are invited to experience the fullness of God’s presence, not through observation, but through the indwelling of His Spirit, shaping our thoughts, actions, and ultimately, our very being.

para_meditar.texto: For the kingdom of God is not meat and drink; but righteousness, and peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.
But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.

2025-12-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for revealing the Kingdom of God not as an external spectacle, but as an internal reality. Help us to seek Your presence within our hearts, to cultivate the seeds of faith, and to allow the Holy Spirit to transform us from the inside out. Grant us the discernment to recognize the Kingdom's presence in our lives, in the righteousness, peace, and joy that comes from knowing You. Guide us to focus on the inner work of spiritual growth, so that we may experience the fullness of Your love and grace. Help us to live lives that reflect the Kingdom within us, sharing Your love and grace with those around us. May we always remember that the Kingdom of God is not found through observation, but through the indwelling of Your Spirit. We surrender our hearts to You, seeking Your will in all things. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-14.versiculo: Mark 2:17 KJV: "When Jesus heard it, he saith unto them, They that are whole have no need of the physician, but they that are sick: I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance."
2025-12-14.reflexion: Today's verse from Mark 2:17 is a powerful reminder of the radical inclusivity of Jesus' mission. He explicitly states that He came not for the 'righteous', those who believe they are already well, but for the 'sinners', those who recognize their need for a physician. This challenges our often-narrow perspective on who is worthy of God's grace. We are prone to judge and exclude, creating barriers based on perceived righteousness or outward appearances. Jesus, however, breaks down these barriers, extending His invitation to all, regardless of their past or present state. He sees the heart, the need, the brokenness that cries out for healing. This verse calls us to introspection. Are we like the 'whole', content in our perceived self-sufficiency, or do we acknowledge our spiritual sickness and need for the Great Physician? It also challenges us to extend the same grace and compassion to others that Jesus extends to us. Instead of judging, we are called to reach out, to love, and to share the good news of repentance and forgiveness. Jesus' message is not about excluding, but about welcoming, embracing, and healing.

para_meditar.texto: Come now, and let us reason together, saith the LORD: though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool.
But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief.

2025-12-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the profound truth revealed in Mark 2:17. We acknowledge our need for You, our dependence on Your grace and mercy. Help us to examine our hearts and to see ourselves as we truly are—sinners in need of a Savior. Open our eyes to the brokenness around us, and grant us the compassion to reach out to others with the same love and acceptance that You have shown to us. Give us the courage to tear down the walls of judgment and exclusion, and to embrace the inclusivity of Your kingdom. Guide us to share the good news of repentance and forgiveness with all whom we encounter, that they too may find healing and wholeness in You. May Your love transform us from the inside out, making us vessels of Your grace and instruments of Your peace. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-15.versiculo: Luke 14:11 KJV: "For whosoever exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted."
2025-12-15.reflexion: Today's verse, Luke 14:11, offers a profound lesson on humility and its ultimate reward. Jesus, in his teaching, underscores a fundamental truth: seeking self-aggrandizement leads to humiliation, while embracing humility leads to exaltation. This principle transcends mere social etiquette; it speaks to the very core of our spiritual journey.  We live in a world that often celebrates outward success and self-promotion. However, Christ calls us to a different standard. True greatness, according to Jesus, is found in serving others and putting their needs before our own. Humility is not weakness; it is strength under control, the ability to recognize our dependence on God and our interconnectedness with others. It’s a constant process of self-examination, acknowledging our flaws, and seeking to grow in grace.  To humble oneself is to relinquish control, to be willing to be last, to serve, and to put the needs of others above our own. This is the path to true exaltation, not in the eyes of the world, but in the eyes of God. It is a promise of spiritual fulfillment and eternal reward.  Let us strive to cultivate humility in our hearts, remembering that the path to greatness is paved with service, sacrifice, and a deep reverence for God and for others.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
By humility and the fear of the Lord are riches, and honour, and life.
And whosoever shall exalt himself shall be abased; and he that shall humble himself shall be exalted.

2025-12-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today seeking guidance in cultivating humility in our lives. We acknowledge our tendency to seek recognition and praise, and we pray for the grace to overcome these desires. Help us to serve others with a heart of love, to put their needs before our own, and to be willing to be last. Grant us the wisdom to see true greatness in humility and the strength to resist the temptations of pride. Open our hearts to the needs of those around us, and give us the courage to act with compassion and kindness. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may reflect the character of Christ in all that we do, walking in humility and grace. We thank you for your love and your promise of exaltation to those who humble themselves before you. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-16.versiculo: Mark 15:39 KJV: "And when the centurion, which stood over against him, saw that he so cried out, and gave up the ghost, he said, Truly this man was the Son of God."
2025-12-16.reflexion: The centurion's declaration in Mark 15:39 is a pivotal moment in the narrative of Jesus' crucifixion. This Roman officer, a man accustomed to death and violence, witnessing the manner of Jesus' death, the loud cry, and the subsequent giving up of the ghost, was compelled to proclaim, "Truly this man was the Son of God." This statement is a testament to the undeniable power of Jesus' sacrifice. It highlights the profound impact of His suffering, not just on those who loved Him, but on those who were present to witness His final moments. The centurion's words are a confession of faith, born not of prior knowledge or belief, but of direct experience. He saw the evidence and, in that moment, recognized the divine nature of Jesus. The cry of Jesus, interpreted by some as a cry of victory, and the remarkable circumstances surrounding His death, broke through the hardened shell of the Roman soldier's skepticism. This verse serves as a powerful reminder that the gospel can penetrate even the most unexpected hearts. It underscores the fact that the truth of Jesus' identity can be revealed not just through miracles and teachings, but also through His suffering and death. The centurion's confession is a call to reflection: Are we, like the centurion, open to recognizing the truth of who Jesus is, even in the midst of difficult circumstances? Do we see the power of God's love in the ultimate sacrifice made for us?

para_meditar.texto: But he was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon him; and with his stripes we are healed.
When Jesus therefore had received the vinegar, he said, It is finished: and he bowed his head, and gave up the ghost.
But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.

2025-12-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you with hearts humbled by the sacrifice of your Son, Jesus Christ. We thank you for the centurion's confession, a testament to the power of your grace and the undeniable truth of Jesus' divinity. Help us, Lord, to see the cross not just as a symbol of suffering, but as a beacon of hope and redemption. Open our hearts to recognize your presence in our lives, even in the midst of trials and tribulations. Grant us the faith to believe in your promises, and the courage to share the good news of Jesus with others. May we live our lives in a way that reflects the love and sacrifice of Jesus, and may our actions and words be a testament to His glory. Guide us to understand the depth of your love and the power of His resurrection, as we strive to live a life worthy of the calling. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-17.versiculo: Philemon 1:16 KJV: "Not now as a servant, but above a servant, a brother beloved, specially to me, but how much more unto thee, both in the flesh, and in the Lord?"
2025-12-17.reflexion: Philemon 1:16 speaks of a transformative relationship, a change from servitude to brotherhood. Paul writes to Philemon, urging him to receive Onesimus, his runaway slave, not as a mere servant but as a beloved brother. This verse highlights the profound impact of the Gospel on human relationships. It underscores the equality we share in Christ. The bond of faith transcends social hierarchies and earthly distinctions. Onesimus, once a slave, is now a brother in the Lord. This transformation is a testament to the redemptive power of Christ's love. It challenges us to view others through the lens of grace, recognizing the inherent dignity and worth of every individual, regardless of their past or present circumstances. Paul emphasizes that if Onesimus is beloved to him, how much more should he be cherished by Philemon, who is also in the faith? This reflects the unity and love that should characterize the body of Christ. We are called to extend forgiveness, reconciliation, and brotherly love to those who have wronged us, just as God has forgiven us. This verse prompts us to examine our own relationships, to consider how we treat those around us, and to strive to embody the transformative love of Christ in our interactions.

para_meditar.texto: There is neither Jew nor Gentile, neither slave nor free, nor is there male and female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus.
Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love; in honour preferring one another;
And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you.

2025-12-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the transformative power of your love, which breaks down barriers and unites us in Christ. Help us to see others as you see them, as brothers and sisters in the faith, regardless of their background or past mistakes. Grant us the grace to extend forgiveness and reconciliation, just as you have forgiven us. Fill our hearts with brotherly love and compassion, that we may treat each other with kindness and respect. Give us the courage to overcome prejudice and embrace the unity that you have called us to. Guide us to reflect your love in all our relationships, that we may be a testament to the Gospel's power to change lives. Help us to remember that we are all children of God, and we are all equal in your eyes. We pray for the ability to love others unconditionally, as you have loved us, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-18.versiculo: 2 Peter 3:10 KJV: "But the day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night; in the which the heavens shall pass away with a great noise, and the elements shall melt with fervent heat, the earth also and the works that are therein shall be burned up."
2025-12-18.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Peter 3:10, offers a stark and sobering perspective on the end times. It reminds us that the return of the Lord will be unexpected, like a thief in the night. This suddenness emphasizes the urgency of our faith and the importance of living each day in readiness. The imagery of the heavens passing away with a great noise and the elements melting with fervent heat paints a picture of complete transformation and judgment. This isn't meant to instill fear, but rather to awaken us to the reality of eternity and the transient nature of earthly things. We are called to live with a sense of anticipation, recognizing that our true citizenship is in heaven. This verse challenges us to prioritize spiritual matters, to store up treasures in heaven, and to live lives of holiness and godliness. Let us not become complacent or distracted by the things of this world, but instead, let us embrace the hope of Christ's return and the promise of a new heaven and a new earth. Let us strive to live each day as if it were our last, making every moment count for the glory of God and the advancement of His kingdom.

para_meditar.texto: Therefore be ye also ready: for in such an hour as ye think not the Son of man cometh.
For yourselves know perfectly that the day of the Lord so cometh as a thief in the night.
And I saw a new heaven and a new earth: for the first heaven and the first earth were passed away; and there was no more sea.

2025-12-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by the reminder in 2 Peter 3:10 of the coming day of the Lord. We acknowledge that earthly things are fleeting, and we pray for the wisdom to focus on eternal matters. Help us to live lives of diligence, holiness, and godliness, preparing our hearts for your return. Grant us the strength to resist the temptations of this world and to seek after your kingdom. Fill us with a sense of anticipation and hope, knowing that you are faithful to your promises. Give us the grace to share the good news of salvation with those around us, that they too may be ready. Help us to be vigilant and watchful, so that we may be found faithful when you come. We pray for strength, guidance, and a deeper understanding of your will for our lives. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-19.versiculo: Ephesians 2:19-22 KJV: "Now therefore ye are no more strangers and foreigners, but fellowcitizens with the saints, and of the household of God; And are built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief corner stone; In whom all the building fitly framed together groweth unto an holy temple in the Lord: In whom ye also are builded together for an habitation of God through the Spirit."
2025-12-19.reflexion: Today's passage from Ephesians paints a glorious picture of our spiritual identity and the unity we share in Christ. We are no longer outsiders, but citizens of God's kingdom, members of His household. This is a radical transformation. Before Christ, we were separated, estranged from God and His people. Now, through faith in Jesus, we are brought near, united with the saints, and welcomed into the very family of God. The foundation upon which this new life is built is the apostles and prophets, with Jesus Christ Himself as the cornerstone. This foundation is solid and secure, ensuring the stability of our faith and the growth of the spiritual temple, which is the Church. We are being built together, each individual stone fitting perfectly into the grand design. This is not a solitary endeavor; it is a communal one. As we are united with other believers, we are being built into a dwelling place for God through the Spirit. This passage calls us to recognize our identity in Christ, embrace our unity with other believers, and actively participate in the building up of the spiritual temple. It reminds us of the profound grace that has brought us into God's family and the responsibility we have to live in a manner worthy of this calling.

para_meditar.texto: Know ye not that ye are the temple of God, and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?
So we, being many, are one body in Christ, and every one members one of another.
Not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together, as the manner of some is; but exhorting one another: and so much the more, as ye see the day approaching.

2025-12-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for your incredible grace and mercy that has made us citizens of your kingdom and members of your household. Thank you for the foundation of faith laid by the apostles and prophets, and most of all, for Jesus Christ, the cornerstone of our lives. Help us to embrace our unity with other believers, recognizing that we are all part of the same body, being built together into a holy temple. Give us the strength and wisdom to live in a manner worthy of our calling, serving you faithfully and loving one another as you have loved us. May we be a dwelling place for your Spirit, reflecting your love and grace to the world. Guide us to actively participate in building up the body of Christ. We thank you for this incredible privilege and for the promise of eternal life, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-20.versiculo: 2 Timothy 3:1-5 KJV: "This know also, that in the last days perilous times shall come. For men shall be lovers of their own selves, covetous, boasters, proud, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy, Without natural affection, trucebreakers, false accusers, incontinent, fierce, despisers of those that are good, Traitors, heady, highminded, lovers of pleasures more than lovers of God; Having a form of godliness, but denying the power thereof: from such turn away."
2025-12-20.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in his second letter to Timothy, offers a stark warning about the perilous times that will characterize the 'last days.' This passage, 2 Timothy 3:1-5, provides a sobering glimpse into the moral decay that will plague humanity. We are warned about a society consumed by self-love, greed, and pride. The list of vices is extensive and paints a picture of a world where the very fabric of human relationships is unraveling. The emphasis is not just on outward actions, but on the inner condition of the heart. The passage highlights a dangerous hypocrisy: people will have a 'form of godliness,' but deny its power. They will outwardly appear religious, yet their lives will not be transformed by the grace of God. This is a call to discernment, urging us to identify and avoid those who profess faith but whose lives contradict their words. We are to be vigilant against the seductive influence of a culture that prioritizes self-gratification and rejects the authority of God. This warning is not just a historical observation; it is a prophetic word for our time, where these very characteristics are increasingly prevalent. We must strive to live lives of genuine faith, rooted in the power of the Holy Spirit, and to be a light in a world shrouded in darkness.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.

Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world. If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him. For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, is not of the Father, but is of the world. And the world passeth away, and the lust thereof: but he that doeth the will of God abideth for ever.

2025-12-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with humble hearts, aware of the warnings in your Word. We see the signs of the times, the growing darkness, and the allure of the world. We confess our own weaknesses and the times we have fallen short. We ask for your grace to discern truth from falsehood, and to resist the temptations that seek to draw us away from you. Strengthen us to love you with all our heart, soul, mind, and strength. Fill us with the Holy Spirit, so that we may bear the fruits of righteousness and be a light in a world desperately in need of your love and truth. Help us to turn away from the deceptive forms of godliness and embrace the power of your presence in our lives. Grant us wisdom, courage, and the discernment to live according to your will, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-21.versiculo: Luke 12:4-5 KJV: "And I say unto you, my friends, Be not afraid of them that kill the body, and after that have no more that they can do. But I will forewarn you whom ye shall fear: Fear him, which after he hath killed hath power to cast into hell; yea, I say unto you, Fear him."
2025-12-21.reflexion: Today's passage from Luke offers a profound perspective on fear and the true source of our reverence. Jesus, addressing his friends, begins by dismissing the fear of those who can only harm the physical body. He acknowledges the reality of earthly threats, the potential for persecution and even death. However, He then redirects our focus, urging us to fear the One who possesses ultimate power – the One who can cast both body and soul into hell. This is not a call to a fear that paralyzes, but a recognition of God's absolute authority and justice. It's a call to reverence and awe, to a deep understanding of His power and our dependence on Him. The fear Jesus speaks of is not the terror of the oppressor, but the respect for the Creator, the Judge, the Redeemer. It's a healthy fear that leads to wisdom, obedience, and a desire to live a life pleasing to Him. This understanding should liberate us from the lesser fears of this world, allowing us to live boldly in faith, knowing that our ultimate security rests in the hands of God. We are reminded that while earthly powers may threaten, their influence is limited. Only God holds the keys to eternity, and it is He whom we must ultimately fear and serve.

para_meditar.texto: The Lord is on my side; I will not fear: what can man do unto me?
Fear thou not; for I am with thee: be not dismayed; for I am thy God: I will strengthen thee; yea, I will help thee; yea, I will uphold thee with the right hand of my righteousness.
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge: but fools despise wisdom and instruction.

2025-12-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the truth revealed in Your Word. We acknowledge Your ultimate power and authority over all things. Help us to cultivate a healthy fear of You, a reverence that leads us to wisdom and obedience. Deliver us from the lesser fears that plague our hearts, the anxieties about the things of this world. Grant us courage to live boldly, knowing that our lives are in Your hands. Strengthen our faith, that we may trust in Your protection and provision. May we always seek to please You in all that we do. Guide us to use our lives for Your glory and to share your love with others. Help us to stand firm in our faith, knowing that nothing can separate us from Your love. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-22.versiculo: Acts 17:11 KJV: "These were more noble than those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the scriptures daily, whether those things were so."
2025-12-22.reflexion: Today's verse highlights the Bereans, described as 'more noble' than the Thessalonians because of their approach to the Gospel. They didn't simply accept Paul and Silas' teachings at face value. Instead, they received the word with 'readiness of mind' and, crucially, 'searched the scriptures daily.' This wasn't a casual glance; it was a diligent, ongoing examination to verify the truth of what they were hearing. This pursuit of truth is a powerful example for us. We are called not to blindly accept doctrines or teachings, but to engage critically and prayerfully with God's Word. The Bereans' 'readiness of mind' suggests an open and teachable spirit, willing to consider new ideas but also grounded in the foundation of Scripture. Their daily searching reveals a commitment to understanding God's truth, not just on Sundays, but in every aspect of their lives. This commitment to verifying the truth through personal study and reflection is essential for spiritual growth and discernment. Are we willing to be like the Bereans, to examine the scriptures daily, to ensure that what we believe aligns with God's revealed truth? This verse encourages us to be active participants in our faith, constantly seeking to understand and live out the principles of God's Word.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.

All scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness: That the man of God may be perfect, thoroughly furnished unto all good works.

For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.

2025-12-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of your Word, a lamp to our feet and a light to our path. Help us to emulate the Bereans, to receive your word with a ready mind and to diligently search the scriptures daily. Grant us the wisdom and discernment to understand your truth, and the courage to live according to it. Open our hearts and minds to your teachings, and help us to be transformed by the renewing of our minds. Give us a hunger for your Word, and a passion to know you more intimately through its study. Help us to be grounded in your truth and to resist the temptation to accept anything that contradicts your Word. Guide us in all things, Lord, and help us to be faithful students of your Word, seeking your will in all we do. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-23.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 6:14 KJV: "Be ye not unequally yoked together with unbelievers: for what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness? and what communion hath light with darkness?"
2025-12-23.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 6:14, serves as a powerful and timeless reminder of the importance of discernment in our relationships. The Apostle Paul urges us to avoid being "unequally yoked" with unbelievers, a metaphor drawn from agriculture where two animals are harnessed together to plow a field. If they are not of equal strength and direction, the task becomes difficult, if not impossible. This principle extends beyond the context of marriage, though that is certainly a critical application. It speaks to all close relationships, partnerships, and collaborations in life. The underlying principle is that believers and unbelievers have fundamentally different worldviews, values, and ultimate goals. Righteousness and unrighteousness are inherently opposed, as are light and darkness. To be unequally yoked is to compromise your faith, potentially leading to spiritual decline and hindering your walk with Christ. This doesn't mean we are to avoid all contact with unbelievers; Jesus Himself ate with sinners. However, it does mean we must carefully consider the nature of our close relationships and ensure they do not compromise our core beliefs and values. We must seek relationships that support and encourage our spiritual growth, rather than hinder it. The pursuit of holiness requires us to make choices that align with our commitment to Christ, even if those choices are difficult or unpopular.

para_meditar.texto: He that walketh with wise men shall be wise: but a companion of fools shall be destroyed.
Be not deceived: evil communications corrupt good manners.
Ye adulterers and adulteresses, know ye not that the friendship of the world is enmity with God? whosoever therefore will be a friend of the world is the enemy of God.

2025-12-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, guide me in all my relationships. Help me to discern the influences in my life and to surround myself with those who will encourage my faith and draw me closer to You. Grant me wisdom to recognize when I am being unequally yoked and the courage to make choices that honor You. Give me strength to stand firm in my beliefs and to seek partnerships that align with Your will. Help me to be a light in the darkness, sharing Your love and truth with those around me, but always protecting my own spiritual health. Protect me from relationships that would lead me astray or compromise my devotion to You. Thank You for Your guidance and protection, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-24.versiculo: Hebrews 2:14-15 KJV: "Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself likewise took part of the same; that through death he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil; And deliver them who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage."
2025-12-24.reflexion: Christmas Eve finds us contemplating the profound victory of Christ over death and the fear it instills. Hebrews 2:14-15 reveals the very core of the Gospel: Jesus, in becoming human, experienced death to conquer its power, which is the devil's dominion. The fear of death, a lifelong burden for humanity, is broken by Christ's sacrifice. This verse speaks of liberation. It is not just freedom from physical death, but from the spiritual bondage that fear creates. The devil uses the fear of death to control and enslave. He thrives on doubt and uncertainty. Christ, however, entered the realm of death, conquered it, and now offers us the ultimate freedom. As we celebrate the birth of Jesus, we celebrate the beginning of this victory. The incarnation, the very act of God becoming man, was a strategic maneuver to dismantle the enemy's stronghold. The cross and resurrection are the ultimate expressions of this victory. Let us remember that we are no longer slaves to fear, but children of God, empowered by the Holy Spirit to live in the light of Christ's resurrection. Embrace the hope of eternal life, the promise of a life lived free from the chains of fear.

para_meditar.texto: Jesus said unto her, I am the resurrection, and the life: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live:
O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory?

For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, Nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.

2025-12-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, as Christmas Eve arrives, we are filled with gratitude for the ultimate sacrifice of your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank you for sending him to conquer death and break the chains of fear that bind us. We acknowledge the power of the enemy to instill fear, but we choose to stand firm in the truth of your Word. Grant us the courage to live boldly, knowing that death has no sting and the grave no victory over those who trust in You. Help us to share this message of hope and freedom with others, that they too may experience the liberating power of the Gospel. Fill us with Your peace, which surpasses all understanding, and help us to remember the true meaning of Christmas. Guide us throughout this season and throughout the coming year, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-25.versiculo: Mark 12:30-31 KJV: "And thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength: this is the first commandment. And the second is like, namely this, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself. There is none other commandment greater than these."
