2025-12-25.reflexion: Christmas Day offers a unique opportunity to reflect on the very essence of our faith: love. Mark 12:30-31 encapsulates the core of Jesus' teachings, declaring that the greatest commandments are to love God with everything we are and to love our neighbor as ourselves. This is not just a suggestion; it's the foundation upon which our relationship with God and others is built. Today, as we celebrate the birth of Jesus, let us examine how well we are embodying these commandments. Do we truly love God with our whole heart, soul, mind, and strength? Are our thoughts, words, and actions reflective of this love? Furthermore, are we extending that same love to our neighbors, regardless of their background, beliefs, or circumstances? The spirit of Christmas is about giving and receiving love. It's about compassion, generosity, and forgiveness. This passage challenges us to make these principles a daily practice, not just a seasonal sentiment. Loving God and loving others are intertwined; one cannot exist without the other. As we unwrap gifts and share meals, let us also unwrap the gift of God's love and share it with the world around us. Let our hearts be filled with gratitude for the ultimate expression of love – the sacrifice of Jesus Christ – and let us strive to live out that love in every aspect of our lives.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
Beloved, let us love one another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of God, and knoweth God. He that loveth not knoweth not God; for God is love.
Owe no man any thing, but to love one another: for he that loveth another hath fulfilled the law.

2025-12-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, on this Christmas Day, we come before you with hearts full of gratitude for the gift of your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank you for the ultimate expression of love, demonstrated through His birth, life, death, and resurrection. Help us, Lord, to love you with all our heart, soul, mind, and strength. May our lives be a testament to our devotion. Grant us the grace to love our neighbors as ourselves, extending compassion, forgiveness, and kindness to all. Guide us to see your image in every person we encounter and to treat them with the love that you have shown us. Fill our hearts with the spirit of Christmas, that we may be generous in giving and receiving love. Help us to embody these commandments daily, not just on this special day, and to live a life that reflects your love to the world. We ask all these things, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-26.versiculo: 1 Peter 2:2-3 KJV: "As newborn babes, desire the sincere milk of the word, that ye may grow thereby: If so be ye have tasted that the Lord is gracious."
2025-12-26.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Peter encourages us to cultivate a hunger for the Word of God, comparing believers to newborn babes who crave milk. This 'sincere milk of the word' is essential for spiritual growth. Just as a baby needs nourishment to thrive physically, we need the spiritual sustenance of Scripture to mature in our faith. The phrase 'if so be ye have tasted that the Lord is gracious' highlights the transformative power of experiencing God's grace. It's not just about reading the Bible; it's about tasting and seeing that God is good. This tasting implies a personal encounter with the Lord, a recognition of His kindness and favor in our lives. This verse calls us to actively seek a deeper understanding of God's Word, to allow it to shape our thoughts, actions, and hearts. By embracing the Scriptures with a childlike eagerness, we open ourselves to the transformative power of God's grace and embark on a journey of spiritual growth and maturity. This growth is not a passive process; it requires a conscious effort to engage with the Word, allowing it to nourish and strengthen our faith. Let us therefore come to God’s word with a desire to be fed and to know His grace more fully.

para_meditar.texto: O taste and see that the Lord is good: blessed is the man that trusteth in him.

For when for the time ye ought to be teachers, ye have need that one teach you again which be the first principles of the oracles of God; and are become such as have need of milk, and not of strong meat. For every one that useth milk is unskilful in the word of righteousness: for he is a babe. But strong meat belongeth to them that are of full age, even those who by reason of use have their senses exercised to discern both good and evil.
But he answered and said, It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.

2025-12-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of Your Word, the sincere milk that nourishes our souls. Help us to approach the Scriptures with the eagerness of newborn babes, desiring to grow and mature in our faith. Grant us a hunger and thirst for Your truth, that we may understand Your grace and experience Your goodness in a deeper way. Open our hearts to receive Your Word, and empower us to live according to its teachings. Help us to taste and see that You are good, and to share this knowledge with others. Guide us in our study and meditation, that we may be transformed by Your truth and become more like Jesus. We pray for strength to resist temptation and to choose to follow your ways. We ask for wisdom, understanding, and discernment as we navigate the challenges of life. We commit our lives to You, seeking to honor You in all we do. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-27.versiculo: Ephesians 1:13-14 KJV: "In whom ye also trusted, after that ye heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation: in whom also after that ye believed, ye were sealed with that holy Spirit of promise, Which is the earnest of our inheritance until the redemption of the purchased possession, unto the praise of his glory."
2025-12-27.reflexion: Today's passage from Ephesians 1:13-14 offers a profound glimpse into the transformative power of the Gospel and the assurance of our inheritance in Christ. The Apostle Paul highlights a sequence of events: hearing the word of truth (the Gospel), believing in Christ, and being sealed with the Holy Spirit. This sealing isn't merely a mark of identification; it's a guarantee, an 'earnest' or down payment, of our future inheritance. This inheritance isn't just a future promise; it's a present reality, experienced through the indwelling of the Holy Spirit. The Holy Spirit's presence is the evidence of our salvation and the assurance of our ultimate redemption. It's a constant reminder of God's faithfulness and the glorious future that awaits us. This passage calls us to reflect on the transformative power of the Gospel in our lives. Have we truly heard and received the word of truth? Do we live in the light of the Holy Spirit's indwelling presence? Are we mindful of our inheritance, the eternal glory that awaits us? Let us live each day with gratitude and hope, knowing that we are sealed by the Holy Spirit, a guarantee of our future glory and a testament to God's unwavering love.

para_meditar.texto: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
Who hath also sealed us, and given the earnest of the Spirit in our hearts.
That the blessing of Abraham might come on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ; that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.

2025-12-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the gift of the Holy Spirit, the seal of our salvation and the earnest of our inheritance. We are grateful for the Gospel of truth, which has brought us to faith in Jesus Christ. Help us to continually hear your word, to believe in it, and to live in the power of the Holy Spirit. Grant us the wisdom to understand the depth of our inheritance, the eternal glory that awaits us. Fill us with the hope and anticipation of your return, and guide us to live lives that are worthy of the Gospel. Strengthen our faith and fill us with your love. We pray for the ability to share the good news with others, that they too may know the joy of salvation and the hope of eternal life. Thank you for your unwavering love and your faithfulness to us, your children. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-28.versiculo: Acts 7:55-56 KJV: "But he, being full of the Holy Ghost, looked up stedfastly into heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing on the right hand of God, And said, Behold, I see the heavens opened, and the Son of man standing on the right hand of God."
2025-12-28.reflexion: Today's passage, Acts 7:55-56, offers a powerful testament to unwavering faith in the face of adversity. Stephen, filled with the Holy Ghost, is about to be stoned for his testimony. Yet, instead of fear, he is filled with the Spirit and sees the glory of God, with Jesus standing at the right hand of the Father. This vision is not just a comfort; it is a declaration of the reality of the spiritual realm, a realm where Jesus intercedes on our behalf. Stephen's steadfast gaze upwards reveals his focus on the eternal, transcending the immediate threat. He is not overwhelmed by the earthly chaos but is anchored by the divine presence. This teaches us the importance of maintaining a heavenly perspective, especially when facing trials. We are reminded that even in moments of persecution, the presence of Jesus is a constant reassurance. Stephen's experience encourages us to seek the filling of the Holy Spirit, to look beyond our circumstances, and to trust in the unwavering love and support of our Savior. Let us strive to emulate Stephen's courage and faith, allowing the Holy Spirit to guide us and open our spiritual eyes to the glory of God.

para_meditar.texto: Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.
What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us?
The Lord is nigh unto them that are of a broken heart; and saveth such as be of a contrite spirit.

2025-12-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the example of Stephen, who, filled with the Holy Spirit, saw Your glory even in the face of death. Help me to cultivate the same spiritual vision, that I might always see Your presence in my life, especially during difficult times. Grant me the courage to look beyond my circumstances and to fix my gaze on Jesus, who is seated at Your right hand, interceding for me. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be strengthened and empowered to share Your truth with boldness and unwavering faith. May I be a vessel of Your love and grace, reflecting Your glory in all that I do. Guide me to trust in Your unwavering presence and comfort me in times of uncertainty. Keep me from being overwhelmed by the trials of this world, but rather, to always be steadfast in my faith. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-29.versiculo: Titus 3:8 KJV: "This is a faithful saying, and these things I will that thou affirm constantly, that they which have believed in God might be careful to maintain good works. These things are good and profitable unto men."
2025-12-29.reflexion: Today's verse, Titus 3:8, is a powerful call to action rooted in the faithfulness of God's word. Paul, writing to Titus, emphasizes that the truths of the Gospel are not merely for intellectual assent, but are meant to transform our lives, leading us to actively pursue good works. The phrase "a faithful saying" underscores the reliability and trustworthiness of the Gospel message.  It's not a suggestion, but a command, a constant affirmation for those who have believed in God. This belief should manifest itself in a life characterized by good works, acts of service, kindness, and righteousness.  The verse highlights the importance of maintaining these good works, suggesting a consistent and deliberate effort.  This isn't about earning salvation, but rather, demonstrating the reality of our faith.  Good works are not just beneficial to others; Paul states that they are "good and profitable unto men." They reflect God's character, bear witness to our faith, and bring glory to Him.  Let us be mindful of the Gospel's call to action, and strive to live lives marked by good works that reflect the love and grace of God.

para_meditar.texto: For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them.
Even so faith, if it hath not works, is dead, being alone.
Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.

2025-12-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for Your faithfulness and for the Gospel that transforms our lives. Help us to understand that our faith is not just a belief, but a call to action. Give us the strength and wisdom to maintain good works, reflecting Your love and grace in all that we do. May our actions be a testament to our faith, bringing glory to Your name. Help us to be mindful of the needs of others and to serve them with a heart of compassion. Guide us to be a blessing to those around us, and may our lives be a shining example of Your goodness. We pray for the grace to overcome any obstacles that hinder us from doing good. We ask for Your guidance in discerning the ways in which we can serve You and others. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may always be motivated by love. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-30.versiculo: Romans 3:23 KJV: "For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God."
2025-12-30.reflexion:
Today's verse, Romans 3:23, presents a stark and universal truth: "For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God." This verse doesn't mince words. It levels the playing field, acknowledging that every single human being, regardless of background, status, or perceived goodness, is touched by sin. The word "all" is inclusive. It leaves no room for exceptions. We have all fallen short. We have all missed the mark. 

The phrase "come short of the glory of God" is profoundly significant. It speaks to the inherent perfection and holiness of God and our inability, in our fallen state, to reflect that glory perfectly. This is not merely a matter of committing occasional wrong actions; it's a condition of our very nature. Sin has corrupted us, separating us from the divine presence and hindering our capacity for true righteousness. 

This verse serves as a foundational truth in the Christian faith. It highlights the need for salvation. If we are all sinners, then we all require a Savior. It underscores the grace of God, who, despite our fallen state, offers redemption and restoration through Jesus Christ. Understanding our sinfulness is the first step towards recognizing our need for God's mercy and accepting the gift of eternal life. It's a humbling truth, but one that opens the door to the greatest hope imaginable.

para_meditar.texto: All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way; and the Lord hath laid on him the iniquity of us all.
If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us.
Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:

2025-12-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today acknowledging the truth of Romans 3:23. We confess that we have all sinned and fallen short of your glory. We have failed to live up to your perfect standard, and we are in desperate need of your grace and mercy. Lord, we are grateful for the sacrifice of Jesus Christ, who bore our sins on the cross. Thank you for the forgiveness offered through his blood. Help us to turn away from sin and to live lives that honor you. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to walk in the light of your truth. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may reflect your glory in all that we do. We surrender our lives to you, trusting in your love and guidance, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-31.versiculo: Philippians 4:13 KJV: "I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me."
2025-12-31.reflexion:
As we approach the end of the year, Philippians 4:13 shines as a beacon of hope and empowerment. This verse isn't just a feel-good quote; it's a profound statement of faith and dependence on Christ. It reminds us that our capabilities are not limited by our own strength or resources, but by the strength that Christ provides. The 'all things' mentioned encompasses every challenge, trial, and opportunity we face. It's not a guarantee of effortless success, but a promise of strength to endure and overcome. 

This verse speaks to the power of the Holy Spirit working within us, enabling us to persevere through difficult circumstances, resist temptation, and accomplish God's will. It calls us to recognize our weakness and to rely on Christ for the power to face each day. As we reflect on the past year, we can see instances where we experienced this truth – times when we felt overwhelmed, yet found the strength to persevere. Let us carry this knowledge into the new year, trusting in Christ's unwavering support and believing that through Him, we can truly do all things.

para_meditar.texto: Fear thou not; for I am with thee: be not dismayed; for I am thy God: I will strengthen thee; yea, I will help thee; yea, I will uphold thee with the right hand of my righteousness.
God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.

And he said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for my strength is made perfect in weakness. Most gladly therefore will I rather glory in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me.

2025-12-31.oracion: Dear Lord, as we stand at the threshold of a new year, we thank you for the strength you have given us throughout the past. We acknowledge our dependence on you and recognize that apart from you, we can do nothing. We pray for the courage to face the challenges ahead, the wisdom to make righteous choices, and the perseverance to walk in your will. Help us to remember Philippians 4:13 and to draw our strength from you in every situation. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, empowering us to live lives that honor you. Grant us the grace to trust in your unwavering love and to believe that through Christ, we can overcome every obstacle. We commit our lives, our hopes, and our future to you, trusting in your guidance and provision, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-01.versiculo: 1 John 3:2 KJV: "Beloved, now are we the sons of God, and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know that, when he shall appear, we shall be like him; for we shall see him as he is."
2026-01-01.reflexion: The Apostle John, in his first epistle, offers a profound glimpse into our present status and future glory. In 1 John 3:2, he declares that we are already the children of God. This is not a promise of future adoption, but a present reality. However, the full extent of what we shall be is yet to be revealed. This mystery, this 'not yet appear,' is a call to faith and anticipation. We are in a state of becoming, a process of transformation that will culminate in our likeness to Christ. John assures us that when Christ appears, we will be like Him because we shall see Him as He is. This isn't just a physical resemblance but a complete spiritual and moral alignment with our Savior. The verse speaks to the hope of our resurrection and the eternal life that awaits believers. It highlights the importance of living a life that reflects our identity as children of God, knowing that our future is secure in Him, even though the fullness of that future remains unseen. We are called to live in the light of this glorious promise, trusting in God's work in us and looking forward to the day of His appearing with eager expectation.

para_meditar.texto: For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us.

For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ: Who shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body, according to the working whereby he is able even to subdue all things unto himself.
When Christ, who is our life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with him in glory.

2026-01-01.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible gift of adoption, that we are now your children. Help us to live in the light of your promise, even when we don't fully understand what the future holds. Grant us faith to trust in your unchanging love and to look forward to the day when we will be like you, seeing you face to face. Give us the strength to live a life that reflects our identity as your children, to pursue holiness, and to love others as you have loved us. We pray for a deeper understanding of your grace and for the ability to patiently await your return. Fill us with hope and joy as we anticipate the unveiling of your glory. We ask all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-02.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 7:23 KJV: "Ye are bought with a price; be not ye the servants of men."
2026-01-02.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 7:23, is a powerful reminder of our freedom in Christ. Paul, addressing the complexities of marriage and social status in the early church, cuts to the heart of the matter: we have been purchased. We are not our own; we belong to God, bought with the ultimate price – the precious blood of Jesus Christ. This understanding liberates us from the shackles of servitude to men, whether in the context of slavery, societal expectations, or the pursuit of worldly approval. It is a call to recognize our inherent value and dignity as children of God, redeemed and set free. This freedom, however, is not a license for selfishness or lawlessness. Instead, it is an invitation to live as servants of Christ, using our liberty to love, serve, and glorify Him. We are called to be mindful of our responsibilities to others, recognizing that our actions reflect our allegiance to the Lord. The verse challenges us to examine the areas where we might be enslaved by the opinions of others, fear, or the pursuit of earthly gain. It encourages us to embrace the freedom Christ has given us and to live a life worthy of our calling, remembering that we are His, and we are to serve Him above all else.

para_meditar.texto: Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and be not entangled again with the yoke of bondage.
But now being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life.
If the Son therefore shall make you free, ye shall be free indeed.

2026-01-02.oracion: Lord, thank you for the incredible gift of freedom You have given us through the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help us to understand the depth of this freedom, that we are no longer slaves to sin or the expectations of the world. Grant us the wisdom to discern the areas where we are still bound and the courage to embrace the truth of our redemption. Give us strength to live lives that honor You, serving others with love and grace. Remind us daily that we belong to You, and that our ultimate allegiance is to Your will. Help us to use our freedom to spread Your love and the Gospel to all those we encounter. Guide us to live as true servants of Christ, always seeking to please You in all that we do. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-03.versiculo: 1 John 3:16 KJV: "Hereby perceive we the love of God, because he laid down his life for us: and we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren."
2026-01-03.reflexion: Today’s verse, 1 John 3:16, unveils the profound depth of God's love and its implications for our lives. It speaks of the ultimate sacrifice – Jesus laying down His life for us. This is the benchmark of love, the purest and most selfless act imaginable.  The verse does not just present a historical event; it sets a standard for our own behavior. We are called to emulate this love, to be willing to lay down our lives for our brothers and sisters.  This doesn't necessarily mean literal martyrdom, although it can. More often, it calls us to a life of sacrificial service, putting the needs of others before our own. It challenges us to love as Christ loved, to extend grace, forgiveness, and compassion even when it’s difficult.  It urges us to consider how we use our time, our resources, and our talents. Are we willing to sacrifice our comfort, our desires, and our ambitions to help others?  The love of Christ compels us. His sacrifice becomes our model, guiding us to live a life that reflects His character, demonstrating love in action.  Let us reflect on how we can better embody this sacrificial love in our daily lives.

para_meditar.texto: Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends.
But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
And walk in love, as Christ also hath loved us, and hath given himself for us an offering and a sacrifice to God for a sweetsmelling savour.

2026-01-03.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the boundless love You demonstrated through the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help me to truly perceive the depth of Your love and to understand the call to love others as Christ loved me. Grant me the strength and the willingness to lay down my own desires and comforts for the sake of my brothers and sisters in Christ. Open my heart to recognize the needs of those around me and give me the courage to act with compassion and selflessness. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may reflect Your love in all that I do, and that my actions may be a testament to Your glory. Guide me to love with a sacrificial heart, just as Jesus loved. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-04.versiculo: 1 Timothy 5:8 KJV: "But if any provide not for his own, and specially for those of his own house, he hath denied the faith, and is worse than an infidel."
2026-01-04.reflexion: Today's verse presents a sobering truth about our responsibility to care for our families. It's not merely a suggestion, but a command with significant spiritual implications. Paul writes that failing to provide for one's own, particularly those in their household, is a denial of the faith. This isn't just about financial provision, though that is certainly included. It encompasses all aspects of care: emotional, spiritual, physical, and practical. It's about being present, involved, and actively working to meet the needs of those closest to us. The verse draws a stark comparison, stating that such a person is 'worse than an infidel.' This highlights the gravity of the situation. It suggests that a lack of care for one's family is a fundamental betrayal of the Christian principles of love, compassion, and responsibility. It underscores the importance of practical Christianity, where faith is demonstrated through actions. We are called to be stewards of God's blessings, and a key way we fulfill that role is by prioritizing the well-being of our families. This verse should prompt us to examine our own lives, to assess how well we are fulfilling this crucial obligation, and to seek God's guidance in becoming better providers and caregivers.

para_meditar.texto: And these words, which I command thee this day, shall be in thine heart: And thou shalt teach them diligently unto thy children, and shalt talk of them when thou sittest in thine house, and when thou walkest by the way, and when thou liest down, and when thou risest up.
A good man leaveth an inheritance to his children's children: and the wealth of the sinner is laid up for the just.
And, ye fathers, provoke not your children to wrath: but bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord.

2026-01-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today acknowledging my responsibility to provide for and care for my family. Forgive me for the times I have fallen short, for the moments I have prioritized other things over their well-being. Grant me wisdom, discernment, and strength to be a faithful steward of the resources you have entrusted to me. Help me to be present in their lives, to nurture them spiritually, and to meet their needs with love and compassion. Guide me in making wise decisions about finances, time, and priorities, so that I can best serve my family and honor you in all that I do. Help me to understand their needs, both seen and unseen, and equip me with the patience and the resources to meet them. Fill my heart with your love, so that I may reflect your grace and mercy to my family. Give me the strength to work diligently and to be a good example of faith, love and obedience. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-05.versiculo: Ephesians 4:29 KJV: "Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but that which is good to the use of edifying, that it may minister grace unto the hearers."
2026-01-05.reflexion: Today's verse, Ephesians 4:29, serves as a powerful reminder of the impact our words have on others. The Apostle Paul urges us to avoid "corrupt communication," which can encompass gossip, negativity, and any speech that tears down rather than builds up. Instead, we are called to speak words that are "good to the use of edifying." This means our words should be constructive, encouraging, and designed to strengthen those who hear them. Think of the ripple effect of positive speech. A kind word can lift someone's spirits, a word of encouragement can fuel their ambition, and a word of grace can offer comfort in times of need. Conversely, harsh words can inflict deep wounds, breed bitterness, and damage relationships. We are called to be stewards of our speech, choosing our words carefully, and ensuring they reflect the love and grace of Christ. Let us strive to be instruments of edification, using our words to build up the body of Christ and minister grace to those around us. This requires intentionality, self-control, and a constant awareness of the power we wield with our tongues. Let our words be a reflection of the Holy Spirit within us, bringing life and hope to a world in need.

para_meditar.texto: A wholesome tongue is a tree of life: but perverseness therein is a breach in the spirit.
Let your speech be alway with grace, seasoned with salt, that ye may know how ye ought to answer every man.
And the tongue is a fire, a world of iniquity: so is the tongue among our members, that it defileth the whole body, and setteth on fire the course of nature; and it is set on fire of hell.

2026-01-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, mindful of the power of my words. I confess that I often fall short, allowing negativity and unkindness to escape my lips. Forgive me, Lord, for the times I have spoken words that have hurt, discouraged, or diminished others. Help me to cultivate a heart that is filled with your love, grace, and compassion. Grant me the wisdom to choose my words carefully, ensuring they are edifying, encouraging, and a reflection of Your character. Fill my mouth with words that bring life and hope to those who hear them. Guide me to speak truth in love, and to always seek to build up the body of Christ. Help me to control my tongue and to speak words that minister grace to the hearers. Thank you for your transforming power. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-06.versiculo: Ephesians 4:22-24 KJV: "That ye put off concerning the former conversation the old man, which is corrupt according to the deceitful lusts; And be renewed in the spirit of your mind; And that ye put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousness and true holiness."
2026-01-06.reflexion: Today's passage calls us to a radical transformation, a complete overhaul of our inner being. It speaks of 'putting off' the old man, the one corrupted by the desires of the flesh, and 'putting on' the new man, created in righteousness and true holiness. This is not a passive process; it's an active decision, a daily commitment. The 'old man' represents our pre-Christian selves, marked by sin, selfishness, and worldly desires. To 'put him off' is to renounce these patterns of thought and behavior. It means recognizing the deceitfulness of our sinful nature and actively resisting its temptations. The key is to be 'renewed in the spirit of your mind'. This renewal is not simply about acquiring new information; it's a spiritual transformation, a changing of our fundamental attitudes and perspectives. It's allowing the Holy Spirit to reshape our thoughts, desires, and intentions. The 'new man' is the person we become in Christ, reflecting His character and living in accordance with His will. This new creation is characterized by righteousness and true holiness, a reflection of God's own nature. This is a lifelong journey, a continual process of growth and sanctification. It requires diligence, self-examination, and a dependence on God's grace. Let us strive to 'put off' the old and 'put on' the new, walking in the newness of life that Christ has given us.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
Lie not one to another, seeing that ye have put off the old man with his deeds; And have put on the new man, which is renewed in knowledge after the image of him that created him.
Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new.

2026-01-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today, acknowledging our need for transformation. Help us to identify the 'old man' within us – the patterns of sin, the selfish desires, and the worldly attitudes that hold us back. Grant us the strength and the courage to 'put off' these things, to renounce them, and to turn away from them. Renew our minds, Lord, by the power of your Holy Spirit. Fill us with your truth, your love, and your wisdom. Help us to see ourselves as you see us, as new creations in Christ, created in righteousness and true holiness. Guide us to 'put on' the new man, to live according to your will, and to reflect your character in all that we do. Help us to walk in the newness of life, moment by moment, with a heart of gratitude and obedience. Give us the grace to persevere in this journey of transformation, knowing that you are always with us. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-07.versiculo: Luke 12:48 KJV: "But he that knew not, and did commit things worthy of stripes, shall be beaten with few stripes. For unto whomsoever much is given, of him shall be much required: and to whom men have committed much, of him they will ask the more."
2026-01-07.reflexion: Today's verse from Luke 12:48 speaks of responsibility and accountability. It underscores the principle that with greater knowledge and privilege comes a greater expectation of conduct. Those who are ignorant, and thus sin, will receive a lesser punishment. However, those who are given much – whether it be resources, influence, or understanding of God's word – will be held to a higher standard. This verse challenges us to reflect on our blessings and the responsibilities that accompany them. Are we using the gifts God has given us to serve Him and others, or are we squandering them? This verse is not meant to instill fear, but rather to motivate us to live a life of purpose and faithfulness. It is a call to steward our resources, talents, and opportunities wisely, knowing that we will one day give an account of how we used them. The more we know, the more we are expected to do. Let us strive to live in accordance with the knowledge we have received, seeking to please God in all that we do.

para_meditar.texto: What doth it profit, my brethren, though a man say he hath faith, and have not works? can faith save him?
His lord said unto him, Well done, thou good and faithful servant: thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord.
Moreover it is required in stewards, that a man be found faithful.

2026-01-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the blessings You have bestowed upon me. I acknowledge that with these blessings come great responsibility. Help me to be a faithful steward of all that You have entrusted to me – my time, my talents, and my resources. Give me the wisdom to discern Your will and the strength to live a life that honors You. Guide me to use my knowledge and understanding to serve others and to bring glory to Your name. Help me to be mindful of the accountability that comes with the gifts I have received. I pray for a heart that is both grateful and obedient, eager to do Your will in all things. Help me to live a life that reflects Your love and grace, and may my actions be a testament to Your goodness. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-08.versiculo: 1 John 3:1 KJV: "Behold, what manner of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called the sons of God: therefore the world knoweth us not, because it knew him not."
2026-01-08.reflexion: The Apostle John opens this verse with a profound exclamation: "Behold, what manner of love..." He invites us to pause and consider the incredible, immeasurable love the Father has poured out upon us. This love isn't just a sentimental feeling; it is an active, sacrificial choice. It is the love that chose us, even before we knew Him. The result of this love is staggering: we are called the sons and daughters of God. We are adopted into His family, given a new identity, and granted access to all the blessings of His kingdom. This verse highlights the contrast between the world and those who belong to God. The world, in its rejection of Christ, cannot understand the depth of God's love or the significance of our relationship with Him. It doesn't recognize us because it didn't recognize Him. This separation should not discourage us, but rather, it should strengthen our resolve to live in accordance with our new identity. We are called to reflect the character of God in our lives, to love as He loves, and to shine His light in a dark world. This verse is a call to gratitude, to a deeper understanding of our identity in Christ, and to a commitment to live lives worthy of the love we have received.

para_meditar.texto: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:
And because ye are sons, God hath sent forth the Spirit of his Son into your hearts, crying, Abba, Father.

2026-01-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, we stand in awe of Your immeasurable love. Thank you for choosing us, for adopting us into Your family, and for calling us Your children. Help us to grasp the depth of Your love, a love that surpasses all understanding. Grant us the grace to live lives that reflect Your character, to love as You love, and to be a light in the darkness. Open our eyes to see the world through Your perspective, and give us strength to remain steadfast in our faith, even when the world doesn't understand. Fill us with Your Spirit, so that we may know and proclaim the truth of who we are in You. Guide us to walk in the fullness of the inheritance we have received. We pray for a deeper understanding of Your love and a greater desire to live a life worthy of Your calling, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-09.versiculo: Mark 4:35 KJV: "And the same day, when the even was come, he saith unto them, Let us pass over unto the other side."
2026-01-09.reflexion: The verse in Mark 4:35, 'And the same day, when the even was come, he saith unto them, Let us pass over unto the other side,' is a powerful call to action, a declaration of purpose, and a foreshadowing of challenges to come. Jesus, having taught parables throughout the day, now directs his disciples to journey to the other side of the lake. This simple command contains profound spiritual lessons. Firstly, it highlights Jesus' intentionality. He doesn't passively wait for things to happen; He actively leads. We are called to be proactive in our faith, not merely observers. Secondly, the command implies a journey. The disciples were not meant to stay where they were; they were to move, to venture into the unknown. Our spiritual lives require a willingness to step out of our comfort zones and follow where God leads, even if it means facing storms. Finally, the verse sets the stage for the coming storm. The journey to the other side wasn't a leisurely cruise; it was a passage through adversity. This teaches us that following Christ doesn't guarantee a life free of trials. In fact, it often means facing them head-on. This verse challenges us to be ready to embark on journeys, trusting in Jesus' guidance, even when the waters become turbulent.

para_meditar.texto: When thou passest through the waters, I will be with thee; and through the rivers, they shall not overflow thee: when thou walkest through the fire, thou shalt not be burned; neither shall the flame kindle upon thee.
Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.
Let your conversation be without covetousness; and be content with such things as ye have: for he hath said, I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee.

2026-01-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the unwavering guidance and protection that You provide. Just as Jesus led his disciples across the lake, I pray that You would lead me through the storms of life. Grant me the courage to follow Your path, even when it seems uncertain, and the faith to trust in Your presence during moments of adversity. Help me to be proactive in my faith, always seeking Your will and purpose for my life. Give me the strength to overcome challenges and the wisdom to learn from them. Thank You for the promise that You will never leave nor forsake me. I surrender my anxieties and fears to You, knowing that You are in control. Guide me to the other side, to the place You have prepared for me. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-10.versiculo: Galatians 6:9 KJV: "And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not."
2026-01-10.reflexion: The Apostle Paul's words in Galatians 6:9 are a powerful encouragement to persevere in our faith and good works. The verse reminds us that the Christian life is not a sprint, but a marathon. There will be times when we feel tired, discouraged, and tempted to give up. The 'well doing' Paul refers to encompasses all aspects of our Christian walk: acts of kindness, acts of service, sharing the Gospel, and enduring trials with faith. It's easy to become weary when we don't see immediate results or when the path ahead seems long and arduous. This verse offers a promise: we will reap a harvest if we do not faint. The 'due season' is not a promise of instant gratification, but rather a reminder that God's timing is perfect. He sees our efforts, knows our struggles, and will bring forth a harvest of blessings if we remain faithful. This verse calls for endurance, patience, and unwavering faith in the face of adversity. It's a call to continue sowing seeds of righteousness, knowing that God will bring forth the fruit in His own time. Let us embrace this truth and press on, knowing that our labor is not in vain.

para_meditar.texto: Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us,
I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
Blessed is the man that endureth temptation: for when he is tried, he shall receive the crown of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love him.

2026-01-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the encouragement of Galatians 6:9. Help me to not grow weary in doing good, even when the path is difficult and the results are not immediately apparent. Grant me the strength and perseverance to continue sowing seeds of faith, hope, and love in all that I do. Give me patience to wait for your perfect timing, trusting that you will bring forth a bountiful harvest in due season. Help me to lay aside the weights that hinder me and to run with endurance the race you have set before me. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, so I may live a life that honors you and reflects your love to others. Guide me to be a beacon of light and a vessel of your grace. I commit my efforts and my weariness to you, trusting in your unfailing promises, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-11.versiculo: Ephesians 6:19-20 KJV: "And for me, that utterance may be given unto me, that I may open my mouth boldly, to make known the mystery of the gospel, For which I am an ambassador in bonds: that therein I may speak boldly, as I ought to speak."
2026-01-11.reflexion: Today's verses from Ephesians offer a powerful reminder of the importance of bold proclamation and prayer for the spread of the Gospel. Paul, writing from prison, doesn't ask for freedom or comfort, but for the ability to speak boldly and clearly about the mystery of the Gospel. He recognizes his role as an ambassador, a representative of Christ, even while bound. This highlights the unwavering commitment required to share the Good News, regardless of personal circumstances. We too, are called to be ambassadors for Christ. We are to be bold in our witness, not shrinking back from opportunities to share the truth. But this boldness is not born of our own strength; it is a gift given by God. We must therefore rely on prayer, asking for the right words, the courage to speak, and the opening of hearts to receive the message. Paul's plea for utterance reminds us that our words are not our own, but instruments through which God works. We are to be vessels, allowing the Holy Spirit to guide our speech and illuminate the Gospel to those who hear it. Let us pray for the same boldness and clarity, that we too may effectively proclaim the mystery of the Gospel.

para_meditar.texto: Commit thy works unto the LORD, and thy thoughts shall be established.

Not that we are sufficient of ourselves to think any thing as of ourselves; but our sufficiency is of God.

2026-01-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts filled with a desire to be faithful witnesses of Your Gospel. We thank You for the example of Paul, who, even in chains, sought only to proclaim Your truth boldly. Grant us, Lord, the same boldness and clarity of speech. Open our mouths that we may share the Good News without fear or hesitation. Give us the wisdom to speak the right words at the right time, and soften the hearts of those who hear. Strengthen us to be ambassadors for Christ in every aspect of our lives, reflecting Your love and grace to the world. Help us to rely on the Holy Spirit for guidance and inspiration. May Your Gospel be proclaimed and may many come to know You. Help us to be bold in our faith, and faithful in our service. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-12.versiculo: 1 Peter 5:8-9 KJV: "Be sober, be vigilant; because your adversary the devil, as a roaring lion, walketh about, seeking whom he may devour: Whom resist stedfast in the faith, knowing that the same afflictions are accomplished in your brethren that are in the world."
2026-01-12.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Peter 5:8-9 serves as a potent reminder of the spiritual battle we face. The Apostle Peter urges us to be 'sober' and 'vigilant,' recognizing that our enemy, the devil, prowls around like a roaring lion, seeking to devour us. This is not a call to fear, but to awareness. The devil's tactics are often subtle, preying on our weaknesses, doubts, and vulnerabilities. He seeks to undermine our faith, sow discord, and lead us astray. However, the passage also offers a powerful antidote: 'Whom resist stedfast in the faith.' This is an active call to stand firm, unwavering in our belief in Jesus Christ. It's a call to rely on the strength and promises found in Scripture. We are not alone in this struggle. Peter reminds us that the same afflictions are experienced by our brethren throughout the world. This shared experience should encourage us and remind us of the unity we have in Christ. It also underscores the importance of supporting and praying for one another as we navigate the challenges of life and resist the devil's attacks. Let us not be caught off guard, but rather, let us arm ourselves with faith, prayer, and the knowledge of God's Word, always ready to resist the enemy and stand firm in the truth.

para_meditar.texto: Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil.
Submit yourselves therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
Casting down imaginations, and every high thing that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ;

2026-01-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the reminder that we are in a spiritual battle. We acknowledge the presence of the enemy and the schemes he uses to tempt and discourage us. Help us to be sober-minded and vigilant, always aware of his attempts to weaken our faith. Strengthen us to resist him, to stand firm in our faith, and to rely on Your Word. Give us the courage to pray without ceasing, and the wisdom to discern his lies from Your truth. Grant us unity with our fellow believers, that we may support and encourage one another in this shared struggle. Protect us from the devil's influence and guide us towards Your will. Fill us with the Holy Spirit, that we may live in victory over temptation and sin. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-13.versiculo: 1 Thessalonians 4:3-5 KJV: "For this is the will of God, even your sanctification, that ye should abstain from fornication: That every one of you should know how to possess his vessel in sanctification and honour; Not in the lust of concupiscence, even as the Gentiles which know not God:"
2026-01-13.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Thessalonians 4:3-5 lays out a clear and challenging instruction: to live a life of holiness, abstaining from sexual immorality. This isn't merely a list of 'do's and don'ts'; it's a call to understand and embrace God's will for our lives. The passage emphasizes that sanctification, or being set apart for God, is the very will of God for us. This process involves a deep understanding of how to 'possess our vessel' – our bodies – in sanctification and honour. It calls us to control our desires, not to be driven by the lusts of the flesh, as the Gentiles who do not know God are. This is a battle fought in the mind, heart, and body. It requires a commitment to prayer, scripture, and fellowship with other believers. The challenge lies in recognizing our own weaknesses and seeking the strength and guidance of the Holy Spirit. We must be diligent in guarding our hearts and minds, avoiding temptation, and cultivating a life of purity that reflects the character of Christ. It's a daily journey of choosing God's will over our own desires, trusting that He will empower us to live a life pleasing to Him.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.

2026-01-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, acknowledging my need for your grace and guidance. I confess that I often struggle with the desires of the flesh and the temptations of this world. I pray for the strength to resist these temptations and to live a life of holiness, as you command in your word. Help me to understand your will for my life, to value my body as a temple of the Holy Spirit, and to honor you in all that I do. Fill me with your Spirit, so that I may walk in righteousness and purity. Grant me discernment to recognize and avoid the pitfalls of sin. Help me to cultivate a heart that is pure and a mind that is focused on you. Thank you for your love, your forgiveness, and your unwavering presence in my life. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-14.versiculo: Acts 17:28 KJV: "For in him we live, and move, and have our being; as certain also of your own poets have said, For we are also his offspring."
2026-01-14.reflexion: Today's verse, Acts 17:28, speaks to the very essence of our existence. It reminds us that God is not distant, but intimately involved in our lives. We are not merely independent beings navigating a chaotic world; rather, we are sustained by Him. The phrase, "in him we live, and move, and have our being," paints a vivid picture of our complete dependence on God. Like a fish in water or air that sustains us, God is the environment in which we exist. He is the source of our life, our energy, and our very identity. This verse echoes the words of the Greek poets, who recognized a similar truth, that we are, in fact, God's offspring. This highlights the universal nature of God's presence, touching all aspects of humanity. This understanding should profoundly impact how we approach life. It calls us to a life of gratitude, recognizing every breath, every movement, every thought as a gift from Him. It compels us to seek a deeper relationship with the One who sustains us. It challenges us to live in accordance with His will, knowing that our purpose is found in Him.

para_meditar.texto: For thou hast possessed my reins: thou hast covered me in my mother's womb. I will praise thee; for I am fearfully and wonderfully made: marvellous are thy works; and that my soul knoweth right well.

For by him were all things created, that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers: all things were created by him, and for him: And he is before all things, and by him all things consist.
All things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made that was made.

2026-01-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts full of gratitude for the incredible gift of life. We acknowledge that in You we live, move, and have our being. Thank you for sustaining us, for providing for us, and for your constant presence in our lives. Help us to recognize your hand in all things, from the smallest detail to the grandest of creations. Open our eyes to see your love and grace in every moment. Grant us the wisdom to live in accordance with your will, and may our actions reflect your glory. Strengthen our faith and deepen our relationship with you. Guide us to live lives that honor you, and may we always remember our dependence on you. We surrender our lives to you, trusting in your infinite love and mercy. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-15.versiculo: Luke 17:6 KJV: "And the Lord said, If ye had faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye might say unto this sycamine tree, Be thou plucked up by the root, and be thou planted in the sea; and it should obey you."
2026-01-15.reflexion: The verse in Luke 17:6, where Jesus speaks of faith as a mustard seed, is a powerful lesson on the transformative potential of even the smallest amount of faith. Jesus uses the imagery of a mustard seed, which is tiny, to illustrate that the size of our faith isn't the primary factor; rather, it's the nature and focus of our faith. The ability to command a tree to uproot itself and be planted in the sea is a hyperbolic expression of the power of faith. It's not about literal tree-moving but about illustrating that with even a little bit of faith, we can overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles. The key is to trust in the power of God, not in our own abilities. This verse challenges us to examine the quality of our faith. Are we trusting in God's promises? Are we believing in His power to work miracles, even in our seemingly impossible situations? It encourages us to cultivate a persistent and unwavering faith, knowing that God can accomplish anything through even the smallest seed of belief. It is a call to action, urging us to step out in faith and trust in God's power, knowing that He is capable of moving mountains in our lives.

2026-01-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of faith, even the smallest measure of it. Strengthen my belief in your ability to move mountains in my life and in the lives of others. Guide me to hear your word and grow my faith daily. Help me to trust you in all things, knowing that you are always with me and that you will never fail me. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, and lead me to a deeper relationship with you, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-16.versiculo: 2 Peter 1:3-4 KJV: "According as his divine power hath given unto us all things that pertain unto life and godliness, through the knowledge of him that hath called us to glory and virtue: Whereby are given unto us exceeding great and precious promises: that by these ye might be partakers of the divine nature, having escaped the corruption that is in the world through lust."
2026-01-16.reflexion: Today's verses, 2 Peter 1:3-4, are a powerful reminder of the abundant provision God has made for us. The Apostle Peter states that through His divine power, we have been given everything we need for life and godliness. This is not a mere promise of future blessings, but a present reality. God has already equipped us with all things necessary to live a life that honors Him. This provision comes through the knowledge of Jesus Christ, who has called us to glory and virtue. This knowledge is not just intellectual understanding, but a deep, personal relationship with Him. Furthermore, these verses highlight the incredible promises God has given us. These promises are exceeding great and precious, offering us the opportunity to become partakers of the divine nature. This means we are not merely spectators of God's glory, but are intimately connected to it. We are invited to escape the corruption that is in the world through lust. This escape is not about isolating ourselves from the world, but about transforming our hearts and minds to align with God's character. We can live a life of holiness and righteousness because He has given us all things that pertain to life and godliness. Let us embrace these promises, live in the power of the Holy Spirit, and pursue a life of ever-increasing godliness.

2026-01-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for your incredible generosity and the provision you offer us. Thank you for giving us everything we need for life and godliness through the knowledge of Jesus Christ. We praise you for the exceeding great and precious promises you have given us, allowing us to partake of your divine nature. Help us to live in the power of the Holy Spirit, escaping the corruption of the world and pursuing a life that is pleasing to you. Grant us the strength to overcome temptation, to walk in righteousness, and to reflect your glory in all that we do. Open our hearts to receive your promises and to trust in your unwavering love. May we always remember that we are called to glory and virtue. We thank you for your grace, mercy, and unending love, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-17.versiculo: Luke 24:49 KJV: "And, behold, I send the promise of my Father upon you: but tarry ye in the city of Jerusalem, until ye be endued with power from on high."
2026-01-17.reflexion: Today's verse, Luke 24:49, is a powerful instruction from the resurrected Christ to his disciples. He commands them to remain in Jerusalem, awaiting the promise of the Father, specifically, the Holy Spirit. This wasn't a suggestion, but a directive, a crucial step before they could begin their ministry. The 'power from on high' refers to the empowerment of the Holy Spirit, the very essence of God's presence and authority. It signifies the ability to preach the Gospel, perform miracles, and live a life of unwavering faith. This verse highlights the importance of preparation and waiting on God's timing. The disciples understood they needed more than just their own abilities; they needed the divine power to be effective witnesses. This reminds us that our own efforts are insufficient without the Holy Spirit's anointing. We too must tarry, seeking His presence, waiting for His guidance and power, before we can truly fulfill the calling He has placed on our lives. This waiting period is not passive; it's a time of prayer, reflection, and anticipation, preparing our hearts to receive the fullness of God's Spirit. The promise of the Father is for us today, just as it was for the disciples. We must be willing to wait, to seek, and to be endued with power from on high to impact the world for Christ.

Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will and the courage to walk in obedience. Strengthen us in our inner man, and help us to bear the fruit of the Spirit in every aspect of our lives. We pray for a fresh outpouring of Your Spirit upon us, so that we may be effective witnesses for Christ in all that we do, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-18.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 3:16 KJV: "Know ye not that ye are the temple of God, and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?"
2026-01-18.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 3:16, is a powerful reminder of our identity in Christ. Paul poses a direct question: "Know ye not that ye are the temple of God, and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?" This isn't merely a statement of fact; it's a call to awareness, a challenge to recognize the sacredness within us. We, the believers, are the temple of God, the dwelling place of His Holy Spirit. This understanding transforms how we view ourselves and how we interact with the world. If the Spirit of God resides within us, then every thought, word, and action should reflect His presence. We are called to be holy, set apart, reflecting the glory of God in all that we do. The implications of this truth are profound. It means we should treat our bodies, minds, and spirits with reverence, understanding that they are vessels of the divine. It also means we should strive to build one another up in faith, as we are all part of the same spiritual temple. The presence of the Holy Spirit empowers us to overcome sin, to love our neighbors, and to share the Gospel. Let us be mindful of this truth, living lives worthy of the temple we are. Let us continually seek the guidance and power of the Holy Spirit, allowing Him to transform us from the inside out.

Guide our thoughts, words, and actions, that everything we do may bring glory to Your name. Help us to build one another up in faith and to be a shining example of Your love and grace. We pray for the strength to nurture the temple of the Holy Spirit that resides within us. We seek your guidance in all things, and we commit our lives to Your service, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-19.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 3:17 KJV: "Now the Lord is that Spirit: and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty."
2026-01-19.reflexion: The verse, 2 Corinthians 3:17, is a beacon of hope and freedom. It unveils a profound truth: the Lord is the Spirit, and where His Spirit resides, there is liberty. This isn't just a physical freedom, but a spiritual one. It's a release from the chains of sin, the bondage of the law, and the constraints of fear. The Spirit of the Lord, the Holy Spirit, brings life and vitality. He empowers us to live in a way that honors God, guiding us away from the old ways and towards the new life in Christ. This liberty is not license to sin, but the power to overcome it. It's the ability to choose righteousness, to walk in love, and to experience the fullness of God's grace.  It’s the freedom to worship, to serve, and to live a life that reflects the glory of God.  Embracing this freedom requires surrendering our lives to the Spirit, allowing Him to transform us from the inside out. We must seek His presence, listen to His voice, and obey His leading. As we do, we will experience the true liberty that comes from knowing and serving the Lord.

2026-01-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the gift of the Holy Spirit and the liberty He brings. We acknowledge that where Your Spirit is, there is true freedom. Open our hearts to hear Your voice and to obey Your leading, so that we may live a life of true freedom and joy. We ask all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-20.versiculo: Romans 5:1 KJV: "Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ:"
2026-01-20.reflexion: Romans 5:1 is a cornerstone of the Christian faith, a declaration of the profound shift that occurs when we are justified by faith. It speaks of a peace that transcends understanding, a peace with God that was previously unattainable. Before Christ, humanity was alienated from God, separated by sin and its consequences. But through faith in Jesus Christ, we are declared righteous in God's eyes. This justification is not earned; it is a free gift, a testament to God's grace and mercy. The verse highlights the transformative power of faith. It is through believing in Jesus, accepting His sacrifice on the cross, and trusting in His resurrection that we are reconciled to God. This reconciliation brings about a profound peace. It's not just the absence of conflict, but a deep, abiding sense of tranquility and wholeness that permeates our lives. This peace is not dependent on our circumstances; it is a constant companion, a refuge in times of trouble, and a source of strength in moments of weakness. This peace is a direct result of our relationship with Jesus Christ, our Lord. He is the mediator, the one who bridges the gap between humanity and God. Through Him, we have access to the Father, and we can experience the fullness of His love and grace. This verse calls us to examine our faith and ensure that it is rooted in the truth of the Gospel. It calls us to embrace the peace that Christ offers and to live lives that reflect our reconciliation with God.

para_meditar.texto: And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.

2026-01-20.oracion: Dear Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of justification through faith in Jesus Christ. Thank you for the peace that surpasses all understanding, the peace that comes from knowing you and being reconciled to you. Help me to cultivate a deeper faith, rooted in the truth of your Word. Help me to trust in your promises and to live a life that reflects the peace that I have received. Grant me the strength to withstand the trials and tribulations of this world, knowing that you are with me always. Fill my heart with your peace, that I may radiate it to others. Guide me in all my ways and keep me focused on Your will. I pray for those who have not yet experienced this peace, that they may come to know you and receive the gift of salvation. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-21.versiculo: John 4:24 KJV: "God is a Spirit: and they that worship him must worship him in spirit and in truth."
2026-01-21.reflexion: John 4:24 unveils a profound truth about the nature of God and the essence of true worship. It declares that God is Spirit, transcending the limitations of physical form and earthly constraints. This fundamental characteristic dictates how we, as His creation, should approach Him. The verse emphasizes that worship must be conducted "in spirit and in truth." This means that worship is not merely a ritualistic performance, a collection of external acts, or a display of outward piety. Instead, it springs from the inner being, from a heart that is genuinely connected to God. It is a response to His presence, an acknowledgment of His sovereignty, and an expression of love and reverence. Furthermore, "in truth" signifies that worship must be authentic, genuine, and aligned with God's revealed will. It rejects hypocrisy and pretense. It demands a life lived in accordance with His teachings, a commitment to His truth, and a desire to please Him in all things. This verse challenges us to examine the state of our hearts, to ensure that our worship is not superficial or routine, but rather a heartfelt and truthful expression of our love and devotion to the Spirit of God. It is a call to seek a deeper intimacy with Him, to cultivate a spirit of humility and obedience, and to live a life that reflects His glory.

para_meditar.texto: I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.

2026-01-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts full of gratitude and reverence. We acknowledge that You are Spirit, and we desire to worship You in spirit and in truth. Help us to strip away the distractions of the world and to focus our hearts on You. Grant us a spirit of humility and teachability, that we may understand Your will and walk in obedience. May our worship be authentic, genuine, and a true reflection of our love for You. Guide us to live lives that honor You in every aspect, from our thoughts to our actions. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may experience Your presence and power in a deeper way. We pray for a heart that is constantly seeking You and longing to please You. Transform our worship and our lives, making them pleasing to You. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-22.versiculo: Acts 4:12 KJV: "Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved."
2026-01-22.reflexion: Today's verse, Acts 4:12, is a cornerstone of Christian belief. It declares that salvation is found exclusively in Jesus Christ. This is not a statement of exclusivity meant to exclude, but a profound declaration of the unique role Jesus plays in God's plan for humanity. The verse emphasizes that no other name, no other philosophy, no other path can offer the same deliverance from sin and reconciliation with God. The name of Jesus is not merely a label; it represents the person, the life, the death, and the resurrection of the Son of God. It is through His sacrifice on the cross that we receive forgiveness and eternal life. This verse challenges us to examine our own beliefs and to assess where we place our hope. Are we relying on our own efforts, our good deeds, or worldly possessions? Or are we placing our trust solely in Jesus Christ? This verse also reminds us of the urgency of sharing the Gospel with others. If salvation is only found in Jesus, then we have a responsibility to proclaim this truth to those who have not heard it. It's a call to action, a reminder that the most important message we can share is the good news of salvation through Jesus Christ.

2026-01-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the gift of Your Son, Jesus Christ. We praise You for the sacrifice He made on the cross, offering us forgiveness and eternal life. Help us to fully embrace the truth of Acts 4:12, understanding that salvation comes only through Jesus. Open our hearts to receive this message and guide us to share it with others. Grant us the courage to stand firm in our faith, knowing that Jesus is the only way to You. Keep us focused on You, Lord, and help us to live each day in a manner that honors You. We ask for Your guidance and wisdom as we navigate this world, and may we always remember the hope we have in Christ. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-23.versiculo: 2 Peter 3:9 KJV: "The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance."
2026-01-23.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Peter 3:9, offers a profound glimpse into the heart of God. It reveals a God who is patient, not slow, in fulfilling His promises. The delay, as some perceive it, is not due to inability or indifference, but rather to His longsuffering towards humanity. The driving force behind this patience is His desire, His will, that 'none should perish, but that all should come to repentance.' This verse is a testament to the immeasurable love and mercy of God. He doesn't delight in the destruction of the wicked, but rather yearns for their transformation, their turning towards Him. It challenges us to re-evaluate our understanding of time and God's actions. What might seem like a delay in His plans is actually an opportunity for others to find salvation. It calls us to view the world through the lens of God's heart, to share His compassion, and to actively participate in the work of bringing others to repentance. We are reminded that God's timing is perfect, and His love extends to every single person. This understanding should inspire us to live lives of patience, grace, and unwavering faith, sharing the Gospel and praying for the salvation of all.

Who will have all men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth.

2026-01-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by Your incredible patience and love. We thank You for Your longsuffering, for Your willingness that none should perish. Give us the strength to share the Gospel with boldness and love, praying for the salvation of every soul. Open our hearts to the needs of others and guide us to be a reflection of Your grace and mercy in all we do. Help us to be patient and trusting in Your perfect plan, knowing that You are working all things for good. May Your will be done on earth as it is in heaven. We commit our lives to You, seeking to honor You in every action and thought. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-24.versiculo: Matthew 10:37-39 KJV: "He that loveth father or mother more than me is not worthy of me: and he that loveth son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me. And he that taketh not his cross, and followeth after me, is not worthy of me. He that findeth his life shall lose it: and he that loseth his life for my sake shall find it."
2026-01-24.reflexion: These verses from Matthew 10 present a stark challenge, a call for radical commitment to Christ. Jesus makes it clear that our love for Him must supersede all other earthly attachments, even the closest familial bonds. This isn't a call to hate our families, but rather to prioritize our relationship with God above all else. It's a recognition that our ultimate allegiance must be to the Kingdom of Heaven. Furthermore, Jesus calls us to 'take up our cross,' a symbol of suffering, sacrifice, and self-denial. This means embracing the hardships and challenges that come with following Him, the willingness to deny ourselves and live a life of obedience. The promise contained in these verses is profound. Losing our life for Christ's sake, denying ourselves and sacrificing our comfort, leads to true life, eternal life. The world's definition of success often involves seeking to gain and hold onto life, but Jesus teaches that genuine fulfillment comes through surrender and sacrifice. This passage reminds us that discipleship demands a complete and unwavering dedication, a willingness to put Christ first in every aspect of our lives.

para_meditar.texto: If any man come to me, and hate not his father, and mother, and wife, and children, and brethren, and sisters, yea, and his own life also, he cannot be my disciple.

But what things were gain to me, those I counted loss for Christ. Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ,
For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us.

2026-01-24.oracion: Lord Jesus, I acknowledge that my love for You should be the greatest love in my life. Forgive me when I have allowed other things, even those I hold dear, to take precedence over You. Help me to prioritize You in all my decisions, thoughts, and actions. Grant me the strength to take up my cross daily, to deny myself, and to follow You wholeheartedly, even when it is difficult. Teach me to embrace sacrifice and suffering for Your sake, knowing that in losing my life for You, I will find true life. Open my eyes to see the eternal reward that awaits those who remain faithful. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be empowered to live a life that is pleasing to You, a life of complete devotion and unwavering obedience. Give me the courage to choose You above all else, and to live a life of eternal purpose, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-25.versiculo: Matthew 6:24 KJV: "No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon."
2026-01-25.reflexion: Today's verse, Matthew 6:24, presents a stark reality: we cannot simultaneously serve God and worldly wealth, often referred to as 'mammon.' This verse is a potent reminder of the fundamental conflict within the human heart. To serve God requires complete devotion, placing Him above all else. This means prioritizing His will, His kingdom, and His values. Serving mammon, on the other hand, involves prioritizing wealth, possessions, and material gain. The verse highlights the inevitable consequence: a divided heart. We will either despise one master while loving the other. This isn't a gentle suggestion; it's a clear warning. The pursuit of wealth can easily become an all-consuming passion, leading us away from spiritual pursuits and fostering a love of the things of this world. The challenge is to discern where our true allegiance lies. Do we seek treasures on earth, or do we seek treasures in heaven? This verse compels us to examine our priorities, our spending habits, and our desires. Are we building our lives on a foundation of faith, or are we chasing the fleeting promises of material prosperity? The choice is ours, and the consequences are eternal.

para_meditar.texto: But my God shall supply all your need according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus.
For the love of money is the root of all evil: which while some coveted after, they have erred from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows.
The blessing of the Lord, it maketh rich, and he addeth no sorrow with it.

2026-01-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, help me to understand the true nature of my heart and the choices I make daily. I confess that I often find myself tempted by the allure of material wealth and the desires of the world. Forgive me for placing anything above You. Grant me the wisdom to discern Your will and to prioritize Your kingdom in every area of my life. Help me to cultivate a heart of contentment, gratitude, and generosity, always seeking to store up treasures in heaven rather than on earth. Strengthen me to resist the temptation to serve mammon, and guide me to serve You with all my heart, soul, mind, and strength. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may live a life of faith and obedience, reflecting Your love and grace to the world. May I always remember that You are my provider, and that all good things come from You. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-26.versiculo: Romans 5:5 KJV: "And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us."
2026-01-26.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 5:5, is a cornerstone of the Christian faith, connecting hope, love, and the Holy Spirit.
