2026-04-04.versiculo: James 1:19-20 KJV: "Wherefore, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath: For the wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of God."
2026-04-04.reflexion: Today's passage from James 1:19-20 offers a powerful call to self-control and spiritual discernment. James, writing to the scattered believers, implores us to cultivate a specific posture: be swift to hear, slow to speak, and slow to wrath. This is not merely good advice; it is a foundational principle for living a righteous life. Being 'swift to hear' emphasizes the importance of listening attentively to God's Word and the wisdom of others. It requires humility and a willingness to learn, setting aside our own preconceived notions and biases. 'Slow to speak' calls us to consider our words carefully. In a world of instant communication, the ability to pause before responding, to weigh our words, and to speak with kindness and truth is a vital spiritual discipline. Finally, James warns against 'wrath,' the uncontrolled, destructive anger that hinders our relationship with God and others. He states unequivocally that the 'wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of God.' Our anger, unchecked, cannot produce the fruits of the Spirit; instead, it breeds conflict, division, and spiritual stagnation. This passage challenges us to cultivate patience, self-control, and a listening heart, enabling us to live a life that reflects the righteousness of God.

2026-04-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, grant me the wisdom and discipline to be swift to hear Your voice, slow to speak, and slow to anger. Help me to be attentive to Your Word, allowing it to shape my thoughts, words, and actions. Forgive me when I am quick to react in anger or speak without considering the impact of my words. Give me the grace to cultivate patience and self-control, so that my life may reflect Your righteousness. Help me to approach every situation with a humble heart, seeking to understand and love others as You have loved me. Fill me with Your Spirit, enabling me to live a life that pleases You and brings glory to Your name. I pray all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-05.versiculo: 1 Thessalonians 1:9-10 KJV: "For they themselves shew of us what manner of entering in we had unto you, and how ye turned to God from idols to serve the living and true God; And to wait for his Son from heaven, whom he raised from the dead, even Jesus, which delivered us from the wrath to come."
2026-04-05.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Thessalonians 1:9-10 paints a powerful picture of transformation and anticipation. Paul commends the Thessalonians for their dramatic shift: they turned away from the emptiness of idolatry and embraced the living and true God. This wasn't a passive change; it was an active 'turning', a conscious decision to abandon the old and embrace the new. This conversion was marked not just by a rejection of false gods, but by a commitment to serve the one true God. Furthermore, their faith extended beyond the present, encompassing a fervent expectation for the return of Christ. They were 'waiting for his Son from heaven,' demonstrating a living hope rooted in the resurrection. This passage challenges us to examine our own lives. Are we truly turned away from idols – anything that vies for our ultimate allegiance? Are we actively serving God, not just in word but in deed? And are we living with an eager anticipation of Christ's return, letting that hope shape our actions and attitudes today? The Thessalonians’ example encourages us to live a life of radical conversion, active service, and unwavering hope in the promise of Christ's return, a life delivered from the wrath to come.

Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth.
Looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ;

2026-04-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the transformative power of your grace. We acknowledge our tendency to cling to idols, both seen and unseen. Help us to turn away from anything that distracts us from you and to embrace a life of active service and devotion. Fill us with an unwavering hope in the promise of Christ’s return. Grant us the patience to wait, the wisdom to understand your will, and the strength to live each day in anticipation of your glorious appearing. May our lives reflect the radical conversion and unwavering faith of the Thessalonians. We pray for a renewed commitment to serve the living and true God, and for a heart filled with the joy of your salvation, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-06.versiculo: James 4:10 KJV: "Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he shall lift you up."
2026-04-06.reflexion: Today's verse, James 4:10, offers a profound invitation: humble yourselves before the Lord. This isn't a call to self-deprecation, but rather a recognition of our true place in the cosmos – as creatures before the Creator. Humility is the cornerstone of the Christian walk. It acknowledges our dependence on God, our fallibility, and our need for His grace. When we humble ourselves, we cast off the pride that blinds us to God's will and hinders our relationship with Him. We become more open to correction, more willing to serve, and more receptive to the blessings God has for us. The promise attached to humility is equally compelling: "He shall lift you up." This isn't a guarantee of immediate material success, but a promise of spiritual elevation. God sees our humility, recognizes our dependence, and responds by drawing us closer, revealing His glory, and empowering us to live lives that are pleasing to Him. It's a reminder that true greatness lies not in self-promotion, but in self-effacement before the Almighty. Let us strive to cultivate humility in our hearts, knowing that in doing so, we are opening ourselves to the transformative power of God's grace.

2026-04-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You with a heart seeking humility. Open my heart to Your teachings, and guide me to live in a way that is pleasing to You. I pray that You would lift me up, not for my own glory, but that I may reflect Your love and light to the world. Strengthen my faith, deepen my understanding of Your Word, and guide me on the path of righteousness. Thank You for Your unwavering love and mercy. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-07.versiculo: Acts 1:8 KJV: "But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth."
2026-04-07.reflexion:
Today's verse, Acts 1:8, is a foundational verse for Christian mission and witness. Jesus, before his ascension, provides his disciples with a powerful promise and a clear commission. He assures them they will receive power after the Holy Spirit comes upon them. This power isn't for personal gain or glory, but for a specific purpose: to be witnesses. The scope of their witness is breathtaking, starting in Jerusalem, expanding to Judaea and Samaria, and ultimately reaching the uttermost part of the earth. 

This verse highlights the essential role of the Holy Spirit in empowering believers for service. The disciples were not to go out and preach in their own strength; they were to wait for the indwelling presence and power of the Holy Spirit. This power is transformative, equipping us with the courage, wisdom, and ability to share the Gospel. Furthermore, the geographical progression underscores the inclusivity of the Gospel message. It's not limited to a specific people or place; it's for everyone, everywhere. We are called to be witnesses in our own Jerusalem (our immediate sphere of influence), expanding outwards to the world around us. This call to witness is a call to action, a call to live a life that reflects the love and grace of God, sharing the good news with those who have yet to hear it.

2026-04-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the promise of the Holy Spirit and the power He gives us. Empower us to be effective witnesses in our Jerusalem, in our Judaea and Samaria, and to the uttermost parts of the earth. Help us to be instruments of your peace and love, bringing hope and salvation to all. Guide us by your Spirit, and fill us with your power to fulfill your calling. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-08.versiculo: John 1:12 KJV: "But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:".
2026-04-08.reflexion: The verse John 1:12 is a cornerstone of Christian faith, offering a profound promise to those who embrace Jesus Christ. It speaks of a transformative power, a divine privilege granted to those who receive him. The act of receiving Christ signifies more than just acknowledging his existence; it is an active choice to welcome him into one's life, to believe in his name, and to trust in his redemptive work. The reward for this acceptance is nothing less than becoming children of God. This verse highlights the radical nature of the Gospel: that through faith in Jesus, we are adopted into God's family, inheriting all the blessings and promises that come with that relationship. It is a call to action, urging us to open our hearts to Christ and experience the life-altering power of his love and grace. This verse is not merely a statement of fact, but an invitation to a new beginning, a new identity, and a new destiny, all rooted in our faith in Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.

Behold, what manner of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called the sons of God: therefore the world knoweth us not, because it knew him not.

2026-04-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the incredible gift of adoption through faith in your Son, Jesus Christ. We praise you for the power to become children of God, a privilege we do not deserve but gratefully receive. Help us to constantly receive and believe in Jesus' name, allowing his love to transform us from the inside out. Grant us the strength to live lives worthy of our calling, reflecting your glory in all that we do. Open our hearts to the work of the Holy Spirit, that we may continually grow in grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior. Guide us to embrace the truth of John 1:12, understanding the profound impact it has on our lives, and empower us to share this good news with others. 2026-04-09.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 5:17 KJV: "Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new."
2026-04-09.reflexion: This powerful verse, 2 Corinthians 5:17, is a cornerstone of Christian faith. It speaks of a radical transformation, a complete renewal that occurs when we accept Christ. The phrase "if any man be in Christ" emphasizes that this change is contingent upon our relationship with Him. It's not merely a matter of following rules or adhering to religious practices; it's about being *in* Christ, intimately connected to Him through faith. The old self, with its sins, failures, and limitations, is declared to be passed away. This is not a gradual process of self-improvement, but a decisive act of God's grace. The old is gone, and behold, all things become new! This newness encompasses not only our spiritual state but also our perspective, our desires, and our very identity. We are no longer defined by our past but by our future in Christ. This verse challenges us to embrace this new creation, to live a life that reflects the radical transformation we have received. It calls us to leave behind the old ways and to walk in the newness of life, empowered by the Holy Spirit.

2026-04-10.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 15:3-4 KJV: "For I delivered unto you first of all that which I also received, how that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures; And that he was buried, and that he rose again the third day according to the scriptures:"

He was buried, confirming His humanity and the reality of His death. Then, the most crucial aspect: He rose again the third day, triumphing over death and offering the promise of eternal life. This resurrection is the cornerstone upon which our faith is built. Without the resurrection, our preaching is vain, and our faith is worthless (1 Corinthians 15:14). This passage calls us to reflect on the immense love of God demonstrated through Christ's sacrifice. It reminds us that our sins are forgiven, and that death no longer has dominion over us. It urges us to live in the light of the resurrection, with hope and confidence in the promise of a future life with Him. Let us embrace this truth, sharing it with others and living lives worthy of the Gospel.

2026-04-11.versiculo: Romans 6:11 KJV: "Likewise reckon ye also yourselves to be dead indeed unto sin, but alive unto God through Jesus Christ our Lord."

This transformation requires a renewed mind, constantly focused on the truth of God's Word and the power of the Holy Spirit working within us. Embrace this freedom, and live a life that reflects your new life in Christ.

2026-04-12.versiculo: John 3:30 KJV: "He must increase, but I must decrease."
2026-04-12.reflexion:
John 3:30 presents a profound truth about the Christian life: the necessity of Christ's increase and our own decrease. John the Baptist, a man of immense popularity and influence, understood this principle intimately. He recognized that his role was to prepare the way for the Messiah, and that his own importance would diminish as Jesus' ministry grew. This is not a call for self-deprecating humility, but a recognition of God's sovereignty and a commitment to His purposes. 

As believers, we are called to embrace this same principle. We are to prioritize Christ, seeking His glory above all else. This means surrendering our own ambitions, desires, and egos to His will. It means actively seeking to understand and live out His teachings, and allowing His character to be formed in us. It also means recognizing that our significance lies not in our own accomplishments, but in our relationship with Him and our participation in His redemptive work.  This is not always easy. Our human nature often resists the idea of decreasing, of fading into the background. But the true joy and fulfillment of the Christian life is found in the increasing presence of Christ in our lives, and allowing Him to be the center of our focus, thoughts, and actions. The more we diminish, the more He shines through us, drawing others to Him.

2026-04-13.versiculo: Romans 15:4 KJV: "For whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the scriptures might have hope."

The Apostle Paul emphasizes that the Old Testament, the 'things written aforetime,' were not merely historical accounts but were penned for our instruction. They serve as a source of learning, teaching us about God's character, His faithfulness, and His dealings with humanity. Through patient study and the comfort found within the Scriptures, we are given the gift of hope. This hope is not a fleeting emotion, but a steadfast anchor for the soul, rooted in the promises of God. The Bible provides us with examples of faith, perseverance, and triumph over adversity. We see the struggles of the patriarchs, the trials of the prophets, and the victories of the kings, all pointing to the ultimate fulfillment of God's plan in Jesus Christ. When we face challenges in our own lives, we can find solace and strength in these narratives. They remind us that we are not alone, that others have walked similar paths, and that God is always present, working all things for good. By immersing ourselves in the Word, we gain the wisdom, patience, and comfort needed to navigate life's complexities and to maintain our hope in Christ.

2026-04-14.versiculo: Luke 2:10-11 KJV: "And the angel said unto them, Fear not: for, behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which shall be to all people. For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord."

"Fear not," the angel declares, immediately calming their apprehension. This is the first act of grace, a reassurance that God's presence, even in its celestial glory, is not to be feared but embraced. The "good tidings of great joy" are not for a select few, but for "all people." This universality is crucial; the Gospel is not a secret, but a message of hope and salvation offered to every individual on Earth. The specific message, "Unto you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord," is the heart of the Gospel. It's a declaration of the birth of Jesus, the promised Messiah, the Savior, and the Lord. This birth in the city of David, fulfilling ancient prophecies, signifies the fulfillment of God's covenant with humanity. The title "Christ" signifies His role as the anointed one, the King. "Lord" acknowledges His divine authority and sovereignty. This simple message carries the weight of eternity, offering redemption, peace, and a new beginning to all who believe. It is a call to abandon fear and embrace the transformative power of God's love, manifested in the birth of His Son.

2026-04-15.versiculo: Galatians 5:1 KJV: "Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and be not entangled again with the yoke of bondage."

The yoke of bondage he warns against can take many forms: legalism, the opinions of others, fear, and even self-condemnation. Christ's sacrifice on the cross broke these chains. We are free to live, to breathe, and to serve Him without the constant weight of guilt or the fear of failure. Standing fast in this liberty requires vigilance and courage. It demands that we actively resist the temptations that would draw us back into the chains of the past. We must constantly remind ourselves of the price that was paid for our freedom and live in accordance with that truth. The prophets, throughout the ages, had foretold a Messiah who would come and offer redemption. Now, Peter proclaims that this Messiah, Jesus, is the one through whom anyone who believes can receive the remission of sins. This is not merely a proclamation of innocence; it's a declaration of restoration, of being set free from the bondage of sin and its consequences. It's a promise of a new beginning, a transformed life, and eternal life. The simplicity of this verse is profound. It doesn't require elaborate rituals or complex theological understanding. It requires faith – a trust in Jesus Christ as the Son of God and the Savior of the world. This verse compels us to examine our own faith. Are we truly believing? 2026-04-17.versiculo: Luke 18:14 KJV: "I tell you, this man went down to his house justified rather than the other: for every one that exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted."
2026-04-17.reflexion: Today's verse from Luke 18:14 presents a powerful lesson on humility and its reward. The parable of the Pharisee and the publican highlights the stark contrast between self-righteousness and genuine repentance. The Pharisee, in his pride, thanks God that he is not like other men, listing his accomplishments and adherence to the law. Conversely, the publican, acknowledging his sinfulness, cries out for mercy. Jesus declares that the publican, not the Pharisee, went home justified. This is not merely a story about outward actions; it's a mirror reflecting the state of our hearts. The Pharisee's pride blinded him to his true condition, while the publican's humility opened him to grace. We are constantly tempted to compare ourselves to others, to measure our worth by worldly standards, and to boast in our own achievements. But true righteousness comes not from self-exaltation, but from recognizing our dependence on God's mercy. This verse challenges us to examine our own hearts. Are we more like the Pharisee, focused on our own perceived merits, or the publican, humbly seeking God's forgiveness? True faith embraces humility, knowing that we are saved by grace, not by our own works. Let us strive to cultivate a heart that is broken before God, recognizing our need for His grace and forgiveness.

2026-04-19.versiculo: Revelation 3:16 KJV: "So then because thou art lukewarm, and neither cold nor hot, I will spue thee out of my mouth."
2026-04-19.reflexion:
Today's verse, Revelation 3:16, is a stark warning to the church of Laodicea, and a timeless lesson for us all. It speaks of lukewarmness – a state of spiritual apathy, neither fully committed to Christ nor actively rejecting Him. The consequences of this lukewarmness are severe: God declares He will 'spue' them out of His mouth. This powerful imagery conveys God's disgust and rejection of those who are neither hot (zealous for Him) nor cold (seeking Him in a sincere way). It highlights the importance of genuine faith and a passionate devotion to Christ. 

Lukewarmness often stems from a comfort in our lives, a complacency that makes us content with a superficial relationship with God. It can manifest in many ways: a lack of prayer, a disinterest in studying the Word, a reluctance to serve others, or a general lack of enthusiasm for the things of God. The danger of lukewarmness is that it deceives us into thinking we are fine, when in reality, we are spiritually malnourished. We must examine our hearts and ask ourselves: Am I fully committed to following Christ? Am I striving to live a life that is pleasing to Him? Let us strive to be 'hot' for God, filled with the fire of the Holy Spirit, and dedicated to living a life worthy of the calling we have received.

2026-04-21.versiculo: James 4:14 KJV: "Whereas ye know not what shall be on the morrow. For what is your life? It is even a vapour, that appeareth for a little time, and then vanisheth away."

He urges us to recognize the uncertainty of the future, the ephemeral existence we experience. He paints a vivid picture: our lives are like a vapor, appearing for a brief moment before disappearing completely. This imagery challenges us to re-evaluate our priorities. We often become consumed by plans, ambitions, and worldly pursuits, forgetting the brevity of our time on earth. The verse calls us to humility, to acknowledge our dependence on God and His sovereign will. It encourages us to live each day with purpose, seeking to glorify God in all that we do. The question is not how long we live, but how well we live. Do we focus on building earthly treasures, or do we invest in eternal ones? Do we live as if tomorrow is guaranteed, or do we embrace the present, mindful of our ultimate destination? This verse is a call to wisdom, urging us to align our lives with God's eternal perspective, making the most of the precious time we have been given, and to live with a sense of urgency, recognizing the brevity of our earthly existence.

2026-04-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts humbled by the truth of James 4:14. We confess our tendency to become preoccupied with the temporal, forgetting the fleeting nature of our lives. Grant us wisdom to number our days and to understand the brevity of our existence. Help us to live each moment with purpose, seeking to glorify You in all that we do. Remind us that our lives are but a vapor, and that our true home is with You. Guide us to invest in eternal treasures, rather than the things of this world. Give us a spirit of diligence, that we may use our time wisely, and not waste the precious gift of life You have bestowed upon us. Help us to live each day with gratitude and a keen awareness of Your presence. Keep us from the illusion of control and help us to embrace Your divine will. We ask all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-22.versiculo: Hebrews 4:12 KJV: "For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart."
2026-04-22.reflexion: Hebrews 4:12 offers a profound glimpse into the nature of God's Word. It's not merely ink on a page; it's alive, active, and incredibly powerful. The passage describes the Word as 'quick,' meaning living and energetic. It's not static; it moves and breathes, capable of transforming lives. It's also 'powerful,' possessing the inherent strength to overcome any obstacle. This power is not brute force, but the divine authority of God. The analogy of a 'twoedged sword' highlights the Word's precision and penetrating ability. It cuts through the superficial, reaching the deepest parts of our being: soul, spirit, joints, and marrow. This cutting action isn't meant to harm, but to reveal and purify. The Word exposes the thoughts and intents of the heart, bringing to light what is hidden. It's a discerner, a judge, capable of discerning the true motives behind our actions and thoughts. This verse calls us to approach Scripture with reverence and openness, allowing it to penetrate and shape our lives. It's a call to engage with the living Word, to allow it to discern and refine us, leading us closer to God.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.
Every word of God is pure: he is a shield unto them that put their trust in him.
In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

2026-04-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the gift of Your Word. We acknowledge that it is living and powerful, sharper than any two-edged sword. We pray for a heart that is receptive to Your Word, a heart that allows it to penetrate and discern our thoughts and intentions. Help us to embrace the truth of Your Word and to allow it to shape our lives, guiding us in all that we do. Grant us the wisdom to understand its depths and the courage to live according to its teachings. Fill us with Your Spirit, that we may be transformed by the renewing of our minds, and that we may walk in accordance with Your will. We ask for Your guidance and strength as we navigate the challenges of this world. May Your Word be a lamp unto our feet and a light unto our path, leading us closer to You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-23.versiculo: John 14:1 KJV: "Let not your heart be troubled: ye believe in God, believe also in me."
2026-04-23.reflexion: John 14:1 is a cornerstone of Christian faith, a balm for the troubled soul. Jesus, knowing His time on earth was drawing to a close, offers these words of comfort to His disciples, and by extension, to all believers. He doesn't promise an easy life, but He does promise peace. The command "Let not your heart be troubled" is not a mere suggestion; it is a directive, a call to action. The heart, the seat of emotions, can be easily overwhelmed by fear, uncertainty, and grief. Jesus acknowledges this and offers a remedy: faith. He connects belief in God with belief in Himself. This is not a new or separate command, but an extension of the first. If we believe in God, the Father, then we must also believe in Jesus, the Son. This verse underscores the unity of the Godhead and the essential nature of faith in both the Father and the Son for true peace. It's a call to trust, to rely on Jesus, even when circumstances seem overwhelming. It's a promise of solace, a refuge from the storms of life, found in the unwavering belief in the love and power of God, demonstrated through Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.
God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.
Thou wilt keep him in perfect peace, whose mind is stayed on thee: because he trusteth in thee.

2026-04-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the words of comfort in John 14:1. I confess that my heart is often troubled by the anxieties of this world. I struggle to trust, to have faith in the face of uncertainty. Help me to truly believe in You, and in Your Son, Jesus Christ. Strengthen my faith, and grant me the peace that surpasses all understanding. Help me to cast all my cares upon You, knowing that You care for me. Fill my heart with Your love and Your presence, so that I may experience the peace that comes from believing in You. Guide me, protect me, and help me to live a life that honors You. Help me to remember that even in the darkest of times, You are with me. Thank you for being my refuge and my strength, my ever-present help in trouble. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-24.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 8:9 KJV: "For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that, though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, that ye through his poverty might be rich."
2026-04-24.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 8:9, presents a profound paradox: the rich becoming poor so that the poor might become rich. This isn't about material wealth alone, but primarily spiritual richness. Jesus, the eternally rich Son of God, willingly emptied Himself, taking on human form and enduring poverty, suffering, and ultimately, death on the cross. He did this for us, for our salvation. He traded His heavenly glory for our earthly struggles. He embraced our poverty of sin, so that we, by faith, could inherit His riches—eternal life, forgiveness, and the indwelling of the Holy Spirit. This verse challenges us to examine our own priorities. Are we clinging to earthly possessions and comforts, or are we willing to embrace the principles of generosity and sacrifice that Christ exemplified? Are we willing to 'become poor' in the eyes of the world, to prioritize the needs of others, and to share the gospel, the greatest treasure of all? This selfless act of Christ should inspire us to live lives of gratitude, generosity, and a willingness to share our blessings with those in need, both spiritually and materially. It is a call to imitate Christ's love and compassion, remembering that true riches are found in Him.

para_meditar.texto: But made himself of no reputation, and took upon him the form of a servant, and was made in the likeness of men:

That they do good, that they be rich in good works, ready to distribute, willing to communicate; Laying up in store for themselves a good foundation against the time to come, that they may lay hold on eternal life.

2026-04-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by the immense sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank you for His grace, that though He was rich, He became poor for our sake. Help us to understand the depth of His love and to live lives that reflect His generosity and selflessness. Grant us a heart that is willing to give, to share, and to prioritize the needs of others. Open our eyes to the spiritual riches that are ours through faith in Jesus. Guide us to lay up treasures in heaven, not on earth. May we always remember that true wealth is found in You, and may we strive to live a life that honors You. Help us to embrace a spirit of giving and sacrifice, reflecting the image of Christ in all that we do. Give us the strength to resist the temptations of earthly possessions and to focus on the eternal. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-25.versiculo: Philippians 2:14-15 KJV: "Do all things without murmurings and disputings: That ye may be blameless and harmless, the sons of God, without rebuke, in the midst of a crooked and perverse nation, among whom ye shine as lights in the world;"
2026-04-25.reflexion: Today's passage from Philippians calls us to a life of purity and radiant witness in a world often marked by negativity and conflict. Paul urges us to do everything "without murmurings and disputings." This speaks to the internal attitude we carry. Murmuring is a symptom of discontent, a grumbling spirit that corrodes our joy and infects those around us. Disputings, on the other hand, involve external conflict, arguments, and disagreements. Both hinder our ability to reflect the light of Christ. The promise, however, is profound. By living without grumbling and disputing, we become "blameless and harmless, the sons of God." This means we are set apart, demonstrating the character of God in our actions and attitudes. We are called to shine as lights in a crooked and perverse nation. Our lives, filled with grace, peace, and love, become a beacon of hope in a world shrouded in darkness. Let us strive to embrace a heart of gratitude and a spirit of unity, allowing our light to illuminate the path for others to find their way to God.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.
Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.
And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.

2026-04-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, help me to live a life that reflects Your light in all I do. Grant me the strength to resist the temptation to murmur and dispute, and fill me with a spirit of gratitude and unity. Help me to see the world through Your eyes, and to be a beacon of hope to those around me. May my actions and words be a testament to Your love and grace. Transform my heart, renew my mind, and guide my steps, that I may be blameless and harmless, a child of God shining brightly in a dark world. Help me to live a life that glorifies Your name and draws others closer to You. I pray this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-26.versiculo: Jude 1:20-21 KJV: "But ye, beloved, building up yourselves on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost, Keep yourselves in the love of God, looking for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life."
2026-04-26.reflexion: Today's scripture, Jude 1:20-21, offers a powerful roadmap for spiritual growth and perseverance. It calls us to a threefold practice: building ourselves up in our faith, praying in the Holy Ghost, and keeping ourselves in the love of God. Building on our most holy faith is not a passive act; it requires diligent study, reflection, and application of God's Word to our lives. It means actively cultivating a deep-rooted belief in Jesus Christ and the truths of the Gospel. Praying in the Holy Ghost is the means by which we connect with God's power and guidance. It's a call to rely on the Holy Spirit for strength, wisdom, and discernment in all aspects of life. The Holy Spirit enables us to pray fervently, intercede for others, and understand God's will. Finally, keeping ourselves in the love of God involves consciously choosing to live in obedience and to experience the boundless love that God offers. This entails a commitment to humility, forgiveness, and a desire to please Him. The promise of eternal life, a precious gift from our Lord Jesus Christ, awaits those who follow these principles. This passage emphasizes the importance of an active faith life, empowering us to live a life pleasing to God, and looking forward to His mercy.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
Praying always with all prayer and supplication in the Spirit, and watching thereunto with all perseverance and supplication for all saints.
And we have known and believed the love that God hath to us. God is love; and he that dwelleth in love dwelleth in God, and God in him.

2026-04-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today, humbled by Your grace and mercy. Thank You for the gift of faith and the promise of eternal life. Help us to build ourselves up on our most holy faith, constantly seeking a deeper understanding of Your Word and Your will for our lives. Guide us to pray in the Holy Ghost, allowing the Holy Spirit to empower us and to guide our prayers. Help us to keep ourselves in Your love, seeking to live in obedience and to experience the fullness of Your love in our lives. Fill us with a longing to know You more intimately. Grant us the strength to persevere in our faith, even in times of difficulty. We pray for wisdom, discernment, and the ability to share Your love with others. We thank You for Your unwavering love and presence in our lives. We lift up our hearts to You, seeking Your guidance and grace, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-27.versiculo: John 15:1 KJV: "I am the true vine, and my Father is the husbandman."
2026-04-27.reflexion: Today, we are invited to meditate on the profound imagery of Jesus as the true vine. In John 15:1, He declares this fundamental truth, setting the stage for a powerful analogy about our relationship with Him and the Father. This verse isn't just a statement; it's a declaration of identity and a call to connection. The Father, the husbandman, diligently tends to the vine, ensuring its health and fruitfulness. We, as branches, are inextricably linked to the vine. Our life source, our sustenance, and our ability to bear fruit are all dependent on our abiding in Christ. This verse challenges us to examine our own connection to the vine. Are we drawing our life from Him? Are we allowing the Father to prune us, to remove anything that hinders our fruitfulness? This is not just a passive relationship. It requires active participation – abiding in Him, listening to His voice, and obeying His commands. The promise is clear: if we remain connected to the true vine, we will bear much fruit, and our joy will be complete. This is a call to a deeper, more intimate relationship with Jesus, a relationship that transforms us and equips us to live a life that glorifies God.

para_meditar.texto: Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit of itself, except it abide in the vine; no more can ye, except ye abide in me.

Being confident of this very thing, that he which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ:

2026-04-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the revelation of Jesus as the true vine. I acknowledge my dependence on Him for all things. Help me to abide in Him daily, to draw my life, strength, and sustenance from Him. Guide me to recognize and embrace the pruning that leads to greater fruitfulness. Grant me the wisdom to listen to Your voice and the courage to obey Your commands. May my life be a testament to Your love and grace, bearing the fruit of the Spirit. Fill me with the joy of knowing You intimately, and help me to reflect Your light to the world. Strengthen my connection to the vine, so that I may grow in faith, love, and obedience. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-28.versiculo: Matthew 7:13-14 KJV: "Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat: Because strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it."
2026-04-28.reflexion: Today's passage from Matthew 7:13-14 presents a stark choice: the wide gate and broad way, leading to destruction, or the narrow gate and the difficult path leading to life. Jesus' words emphasize the importance of making a conscious decision about the direction of our lives. The 'wide gate' represents the path of least resistance, the one that caters to our desires and worldly ambitions. It's the path of ease and popularity, where many choose to walk. This path often involves compromises in our faith, a disregard for biblical principles, and a focus on fleeting pleasures. However, this path ultimately leads to destruction, a separation from God and eternal life. The 'narrow gate,' in contrast, requires effort, discipline, and a commitment to righteousness. It is a path of self-denial, where we must choose to follow Christ's teachings, even when it's challenging. This path may be less traveled, but it leads to life, to a deeper relationship with God, and to the promise of eternal salvation. The passage serves as a powerful reminder to examine our hearts and to consciously choose the path that aligns with God's will. It calls us to be vigilant in our choices, recognizing that every decision we make contributes to the path we are on. The narrow way is not easy, but it is the only way to lasting joy and fulfillment.

para_meditar.texto: There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death.
Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me.

Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us, Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.

2026-04-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with a humble heart, acknowledging the choices we face daily. Help us to discern the path that leads to life, the narrow gate that leads to you. Grant us the strength to resist the temptations of the wide gate, the ease and comfort that lead to destruction. Guide us with your Holy Spirit, that we may choose the path of righteousness, seeking your will in all things. Give us the courage to embrace the challenges of the narrow way, knowing that it leads to eternal life and a closer relationship with you. Help us to stay focused on you, Lord. Help us to follow your example and always choose the path that pleases you. Thank you for your love and your guidance. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-29.versiculo: Galatians 6:7-8 KJV: "Be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap. For he that soweth to his flesh shall of the flesh reap corruption; but he that soweth to the Spirit shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting."
2026-04-29.reflexion: Today's passage from Galatians 6:7-8 speaks to the fundamental principle of sowing and reaping, a truth woven into the fabric of the universe. We are not immune to this law; what we plant, we will harvest. This isn't just about farming; it applies to every aspect of our lives. The 'sowing' represents our actions, thoughts, and choices. 'Reaping' is the inevitable consequence, the harvest of what we've planted. The Apostle Paul warns against being deceived, reminding us that God cannot be mocked. He sees our hearts and knows our intentions. The passage contrasts two types of sowing: sowing to the flesh and sowing to the Spirit. Sowing to the flesh, characterized by indulging in sinful desires and worldly pursuits, leads to corruption and ultimately, spiritual death. It's a path of fleeting pleasure and lasting emptiness. Conversely, sowing to the Spirit, by cultivating righteousness, obedience, and a relationship with God, leads to eternal life. This requires a deliberate effort to cultivate the fruits of the Spirit: love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance (Galatians 5:22-23). We must be mindful of what we 'plant' each day, choosing actions and thoughts that align with God's will, knowing that the harvest we reap will be according to what we sow. Let us strive to sow seeds of the Spirit, and reap the eternal rewards of righteousness and life with Christ.

para_meditar.texto: The wicked worketh a deceitful work: but to him that soweth righteousness shall be a sure reward.
For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.
But this I say, He which soweth sparingly shall reap also sparingly; and he which soweth bountifully shall reap also bountifully.

2026-04-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today, acknowledging the truth of Your Word regarding sowing and reaping. Forgive me for the times I have sown to the flesh, pursuing selfish desires and worldly pleasures. Help me to recognize the seeds I am planting in my life each day, and to make choices that align with Your will. Grant me the strength to resist temptation and to cultivate the fruits of the Spirit: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control. Guide me to sow seeds of righteousness, and to reap a harvest of eternal life. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may walk in Your ways and bring glory to Your name. I pray for discernment to know Your will and the courage to follow it, always choosing to sow seeds of the Spirit. May my life be a testimony to Your grace and faithfulness, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-30.versiculo: Acts 9:3-6 KJV: "And as he journeyed, he came near Damascus: and suddenly there shined round about him a light from heaven: And he fell to the earth, and heard a voice saying unto him, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? And he said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks. And he trembling and astonished said, Lord, what wilt thou have me to do? And the Lord said unto him, Arise, and go into the city, and it shall be told thee what thou must do."
2026-04-30.reflexion: The dramatic encounter of Saul, later Paul, on the road to Damascus is a cornerstone of Christian faith. Acts 9:3-6 depicts a moment of radical transformation. Saul, a zealous persecutor of Christians, is struck down by a blinding light and hears the voice of Jesus. This wasn't a gentle nudge, but a forceful intervention. The question, "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?" is a direct challenge to his actions. The Lord identifies Himself as the one being persecuted, highlighting the intimate connection between Christ and His followers. Saul's response, marked by trembling and astonishment, is a crucial turning point. He doesn't argue or question further; instead, he immediately asks, "Lord, what wilt thou have me to do?" This humble surrender is the hallmark of genuine repentance and faith. The Lord’s response, instructing him to go into the city and await further instructions, emphasizes the importance of obedience and reliance on God's plan. This passage reminds us that God can transform even the most hardened hearts and that true faith begins with a willingness to submit to His will. We are challenged to examine our own lives, to recognize the areas where we might be resistant to God's leading, and to respond with the same humble obedience as Saul.

2026-04-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the transformative power of Your grace. Just as You revealed Yourself to Saul on the road to Damascus, open our eyes to Your presence in our lives. Help us to recognize areas where we may be straying from Your path, and give us the courage to surrender our wills to Yours. Grant us a humble and obedient heart, ready to follow Your leading in all things. Fill us with the same awe and reverence that Saul experienced, and empower us to ask, "Lord, what wilt thou have me to do?" Help us to be transformed by the renewing of our minds, and to walk in the newness of life You have given us. Guide us to be faithful witnesses of Your love and mercy, shining Your light into a dark world. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-01.versiculo: Romans 13:8 KJV: "Owe no man any thing, but to love one another: for he that loveth another hath fulfilled the law."
2026-05-01.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 13:8, presents a profound truth about our obligations and the essence of Christian living. The Apostle Paul urges us to 'owe no man anything, but to love one another.' This is more than a simple suggestion; it's a fundamental principle. The implication is clear: financial debts can be paid, but the debt of love is a continuous and unending obligation. We are perpetually called to love our neighbor. This love, as described in the Bible, is not merely an emotion, but an active, sacrificial commitment. It’s a love that mirrors Christ's love for us. When we love others, we fulfill the law. This doesn't mean we earn our salvation through love, but rather, that love is the natural outflow of a heart transformed by grace. Loving others is the evidence of our faith, the proof that the Holy Spirit dwells within us. It encompasses kindness, patience, forgiveness, and a genuine concern for the well-being of others. In a world often characterized by selfishness and indifference, this verse challenges us to examine our hearts and to prioritize love above all else. Are we actively loving our neighbors, or are we withholding love, affection or help? Let us seek to live out this call to love, recognizing that in doing so, we are fulfilling the very heart of God's law.

2026-05-01.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts open to Your Word. We thank You for the clear command to love one another, a command that reflects Your very nature. Help us to understand the depth and breadth of this love, a love that is patient, kind, and selfless. Forgive us for the times we have failed to love, for the moments when we have prioritized our own needs above those of others. Grant us the grace to love our neighbors, our enemies, and all those around us, as You have loved us. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, so that love may flow freely from our hearts, transforming our lives and the lives of those we encounter. Give us the strength to overcome selfishness and to serve others with humility and compassion. Help us to reflect Your love in all that we say and do, so that others may see You in us. We ask this, believing in Your infinite mercy, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-02.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 5:18-19 KJV: "And all things are of God, who hath reconciled us to himself by Jesus Christ, and hath given to us the ministry of reconciliation; To wit, that God was in Christ, reconciling the world unto himself, not imputing their trespasses unto them; and hath committed unto us the word of reconciliation."
2026-05-02.reflexion: Today's passage from 2 Corinthians speaks of the profound transformation that takes place in the believer through Christ. We are reminded that God, through Jesus, has reconciled us to Himself. This isn't just a passive act; it is an active, loving initiative from God's side. He didn't wait for us to fix ourselves; He came down and did the work. The beauty lies in the 'ministry of reconciliation' given to us. We are not just recipients of this reconciliation; we are now called to participate in it. We are given the privilege of sharing the Good News, the word of reconciliation, with a world desperately in need of it. This verse highlights the heart of the Gospel: God's love, His forgiveness, and His desire for a relationship with humanity. It is a call to action, urging us to share the message of hope, peace, and forgiveness with those around us. We are ambassadors for Christ, tasked with representing His love and grace to a broken world. Let us embrace this ministry with humility, gratitude, and a fervent desire to see others experience the same transformative power of God's reconciliation.

2026-05-02.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the incredible gift of reconciliation through Jesus Christ. Thank You for not holding our sins against us, but for offering us forgiveness and a renewed relationship with You. Help us to understand the depth of Your love and grace, and to live in a manner worthy of the Gospel. Give us the strength and the courage to share the message of reconciliation with those who have not yet experienced Your love. Open our hearts to see the world through Your eyes, and to be a light of hope in the darkness. Empower us to be effective ambassadors for Christ, sharing the Good News with humility and compassion. Guide us in all our endeavors, so that Your name may be glorified. We pray for those who are lost, that they may find their way to You. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-03.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 13:4-7 KJV: "Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; Beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things."
2026-05-03.reflexion: Today's passage, 1 Corinthians 13:4-7, paints a vivid portrait of love, not just as a feeling, but as an action. It's a love that 'suffereth long,' patiently enduring even in the face of adversity. It is 'kind,' extending grace and compassion to others. True love 'envieth not,' a reminder to rejoice in the blessings of others rather than harboring resentment. It is humble, 'vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up,' and does not seek self-glory. This love is not selfish; it 'seeketh not her own' but prioritizes the needs of others. It is patient, 'not easily provoked,' and forgiving, 'thinketh no evil.' Furthermore, it rejoices in truth and endures through all circumstances, bearing, believing, hoping, and enduring all things. This passage challenges us to examine the love we extend to others. Are we patient? Are we kind? Do we truly seek the good of those around us? This is a call to action, a reminder that love is not just a word, but a way of life, reflecting the very nature of God.

2026-05-03.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the beautiful definition of love found in 1 Corinthians 13. Help us to embody this love in our daily lives. Grant us patience when we are challenged, kindness towards those we encounter, and a heart that rejoices in the truth. Help us to be humble, to seek the good of others above our own, and to forgive readily. Fill us with Your Spirit so that we may bear, believe, hope, and endure all things. May we reflect Your love to the world, showing the unwavering grace and compassion that You have shown to us. Guide us to love as You love, unconditionally and without measure. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-04.versiculo: Romans 3:28 KJV: "Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the law."
2026-05-04.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 3:28, is a cornerstone of Christian theology. It declares a foundational truth: justification, or being declared righteous in God's eyes, is received not through our adherence to the law, but solely through faith. This doesn't negate the importance of good works; rather, it establishes the source of our righteousness. We are justified *by faith*. The 'deeds of the law' here refer to the Mosaic Law, including its intricate rituals and commandments, which, while good, could not ultimately earn salvation. The law reveals our sin and our inability to meet God's perfect standard. Faith, on the other hand, is the open hand that receives God's grace, freely offered through the sacrifice of Jesus Christ. It is a trust, a reliance on His finished work on the cross. This verse points us to the heart of the Gospel: it's not about what we do, but about what Christ has already done for us. We are saved by grace, through faith, not by our own works, lest any man should boast. This understanding is not a license for lawlessness, but a liberation from the burden of earning salvation. It frees us to live lives of gratitude and obedience, empowered by the Holy Spirit, reflecting the love and grace we have received.

para_meditar.texto: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.

Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by the faith of Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ, and not by the works of the law: for by the works of the law shall no flesh be justified.
Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;

2026-05-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the profound truth of Romans 3:28. Thank You for the gift of justification through faith in Jesus Christ. Help me to grasp the depth of Your grace and to live in the freedom that comes from knowing I am declared righteous, not by my own efforts, but by Your perfect sacrifice. Open my heart to trust You completely, to lean on Your promises, and to walk in obedience, not to earn Your favor, but out of gratitude for Your immeasurable love. Grant me the wisdom to understand that good works are the fruit of faith, a natural outflow of the transformed life. Help me to always remember that salvation is a free gift, and to share this good news with others. Give me strength to live a life that honors You, reflecting Your glory in all I do, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-05.versiculo: Colossians 3:5 KJV: "Mortify therefore your members which are upon the earth; fornication, uncleanness, inordinate affection, evil concupiscence, and covetousness, which is idolatry:"
2026-05-05.reflexion: Today's verse calls us to a radical act of spiritual surgery: mortification. We are commanded to 'mortify' – to put to death – those earthly members that lead us away from God. These aren't just external actions; they are the internal desires and affections that drive our behavior. The list provided, 'fornication, uncleanness, inordinate affection, evil concupiscence, and covetousness,' reveals the breadth of this struggle. It's a battle against lust, impurity, excessive desires, and the worship of things. Covetousness, the insatiable desire for more, is explicitly labeled as idolatry, highlighting the grave nature of these sins. This verse isn't just about avoiding specific actions; it's about a fundamental shift in our hearts. It's about aligning our desires with God's will, prioritizing His kingdom, and recognizing that true satisfaction comes not from earthly pleasures, but from a deep and abiding relationship with Him. To live a truly Christian life, we must actively and intentionally kill the desires of the flesh, replacing them with the fruits of the Spirit.

para_meditar.texto: For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.
And they that are Christ's have crucified the flesh with the affections and lusts.
For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, is not of the Father, but is of the world.

2026-05-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today seeking your grace and strength. I confess that I often struggle with the earthly desires that war against my soul. Forgive me for the times I have indulged in fornication, impurity, and covetousness. Help me to mortify these members, to put to death the desires that lead me astray. Grant me the power of your Holy Spirit to resist temptation and to cultivate a heart that is set on things above. Fill me with a deep longing for your presence and your will. Help me to prioritize your kingdom and to find my satisfaction in you alone. Guide me to a life of holiness and righteousness, reflecting your love and glory in all that I do. Give me the strength to overcome the flesh and live a life pleasing to You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-06.versiculo: Jude 1:24-25 KJV: "Now unto him that is able to keep you from falling, and to present you faultless before the presence of his glory with exceeding joy, To the only wise God our Saviour, be glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and ever. Amen."
2026-05-06.reflexion: Today's passage from Jude is a powerful reminder of God's unwavering grace and our ultimate hope. The verse speaks of God's ability to 'keep you from falling.' This isn't just a passive protection; it's an active, ongoing work of God in our lives. He shields us from the snares of sin, the temptations of the world, and the attacks of the enemy. Furthermore, He promises to 'present you faultless before the presence of his glory with exceeding joy.' This is not through our own merit, but through the atoning sacrifice of Jesus Christ. It is a promise of complete restoration and a joyous reunion with our Savior. The passage concludes with a doxology, a declaration of praise and honor to God. We are called to recognize His wisdom, His saving power, His dominion, and His power, both now and forever. This verse invites us to live in constant awareness of God's presence and provision, trusting in His ability to keep us and rejoicing in the glorious future He has prepared for us. Let us embrace this truth and live with the joyful expectation of His return, continually praising Him for His boundless love and grace.

para_meditar.texto: He will not let your foot slip— he who watches over you will not slumber.

For I am convinced that neither death nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither the present nor the future, nor any powers, neither height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Being confident of this, that he who began a good work in you will carry it on to completion until the day of Christ Jesus.

2026-05-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible promise found in Jude 1:24-25. Thank you for your ability to keep us from falling and for the assurance that you will present us blameless before your glorious presence. We praise you for your wisdom, your saving power, your dominion, and your power. Help us to live each day in the awareness of your constant protection and provision. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to walk in the light of your truth. Fill our hearts with exceeding joy, knowing that we are loved and redeemed by you. Guide us in all our ways, and may our lives be a testament to your glory, now and forever. We humbly offer this prayer in the name of Jesus, amen.
